</TD></TR>
<TR><TD valign=top width=22><P>&nbsp;</P></TD><TD valign=top width=233.6><P>&nbsp;</P></TD><TD valign=top width=15.733><P>&nbsp;</P></TD><TD valign=top width=87.733><P>&nbsp;</P></TD><TD valign=top width=15.733><P>&nbsp;</P></TD><TD valign=top width=88.267><P>&nbsp;</P></TD></TR>
</TABLE>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>Holders of Record</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>At January 30, 2008, there were 77 record holders of the Company's common stock. &nbsp;The closing price for the Company's common stock at December 31, 2007 was $9.05.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Our ability to utilize our Federal Net Operating Loss Carrryforwards (&quot;NOLs&quot;) would be substantially reduced if AMIC were to undergo an &quot;ownership change&quot; within the meaning of Section 382(g)(1) of the Internal Revenue Code. &nbsp;AMIC will be treated as having had an &quot;ownership change&quot; if there is more than a 50% increase in stock ownership during a three year '&quot;testing period&quot; by &quot;5% stockholders&quot;. &nbsp;In order to reduce the risk of an ownership change, in November 2002, AMIC's stockholders approved an amendment to its Certificate of Incorporation restricting transfers of shares of its common stock that could result in the imposition of limitations on the use, for federal, state and city income tax purposes, of AMIC's carryforwards of net operating losses and certain federal income tax credits. &nbsp;The Certificate of Incorporation generally restricts any person from attempting to s
ell, transfer or dispose, or purchase or acquire any AMIC stock, if such transfer would affect the percentage of AMIC stock owned by a 5% stockholder. &nbsp;Any person attempting such a transfer will be required, prior to the date of any proposed transfer, to request in writing that the board of directors review the proposed transfer and </P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="line-height:13pt; margin:0px; font-family:Arial; font-size:11pt">15</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial; page-break-before:always" align=justify>authorize or not authorize such proposed transfer. &nbsp;Any attempted transfer made in violation of the stock transfer restrictions will be null and void. &nbsp;In the event of an attempted or purported transfer involving a sale or disposition of capital stock in violation of stock transfer restrictions, the transferor shall remain the owner of such shares. &nbsp;Notwithstanding such transfer restrictions, there could be circumstances under which an issuance by AMIC of a significant number of new shares of Common Stock or other new class of equity security having certain characteristics (for example, the right to vote or convert into Common Stock) might result in an ownership change under the Code.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>Dividends</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The Company does not have any legal restriction on paying dividends, and no dividend on the Company&#146;s stock was declared during 2007.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>Securities Authorized for Issuance Under Equity Compensation Plans</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The information under the heading &#147;Equity Compensation Plan Information&#148; in the Company&#146;s definitive proxy statement for the 2008 annual meeting of stockholders is incorporated herein by reference.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>Issuer Purchases of Equity Securities</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The Company did not repurchase any of its outstanding equity securities during the quarter ended December 31, 2007.</P>
<P style="margin-top:13.333px; margin-bottom:-16px; padding-left:-7.333px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>Item 6.</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:-7.333px; text-indent:55.333px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B><I>Selected Financial Data</I></B></P>
<P style="margin-top:13.333px; margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Not applicable</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-16px; padding-left:-7.333px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>Item 7.</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:-7.333px; text-indent:66px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B><I>Management's Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations</I></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>Overview</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>We are an insurance holding company engaged in the insurance and reinsurance business through our wholly owned insurance company, Independence American Insurance Company (&quot;Independence American&quot;) and our marketing organizations, including our three medical stop-loss managing general underwriter subsidiaries (&#147;our MGUs&quot;). &nbsp;Since November 2002, AMIC has been affiliated with Independence Holding Company (&quot;IHC&quot;), which currently owns 49.7% of AMIC's stock, and IHC's senior management has provided direction to the Company through service agreements between the Company and IHC. &nbsp;In 2007, Independence American&#146;s primary source of revenue was reinsurance premiums. &nbsp;The majority of these premiums are ceded to Independence American from IHC under long-term reinsurance treaties to cede its gross medical stop-loss premiums written to Independence American. &nbsp;In addition, Independence American as
sumes fully insured health and short-term statutory disability benefit product in New York State (&quot;DBL&quot;) premiums from IHC, and assumes medical stop-loss premiums from unaffiliated carriers. &nbsp;In 2007, Independence American began writing small-group major medical, medical stop-loss, major medical plans for individuals and families, and short-term medical. &nbsp;Given its enhanced A- (Excellent) rating from A.M. Best, Independence American expects to expand the distribution of its medical stop-loss products through our MGUs, and increase significantly the business written on its paper, especially major medical plans for individuals and families.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>While management considers a wide range of factors in its strategic planning, the overriding consideration is underwriting profitability. &nbsp;Management's assessment of trends in healthcare and in the medical stop-loss market play a significant role in determining whether to expand Independence American's reinsurance participation percentage or the number of programs it reinsures. &nbsp;Since Independence American reinsures a portion of all of the business produced by our MGUs, and since these companies are also eligible to earn profit sharing commissions based on the profitability of the business they place, our MGUs also emphasize underwriting profitability. &nbsp;In addition, management focuses on controlling operating costs. &nbsp;By sharing employees with IHC and sharing resources among our subsidiaries, we strive to maximize our earnings.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="line-height:13pt; margin:0px; font-family:Arial; font-size:11pt">16</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial; page-break-before:always" align=justify>The following is a summary of key performance information and events:</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>

<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-16px; padding-left:48px; text-indent:-24px; font-family:Symbol" align=justify>&#183;</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The Book Value of the Company increased to $9.96 at December 31, 2007, from $9.82 at December 31, 2006.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-16px; padding-left:48px; text-indent:-24px; font-family:Symbol" align=justify>&#183;</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Of the aggregate carrying value of the Company&#146;s investment assets, approximately 93.9% was invested in investment grade fixed maturities, securities purchased under resale agreements, and cash and cash equivalents at December 31, 2007. Also at such date, approximately 99.7% of the Company's fixed maturities were investment grade.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-16px; padding-left:48px; text-indent:-24px; font-family:Symbol">&#183;</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:48px; font-family:Arial">On October 5, 2007, the Company acquired certain assets, including a 51% interest in HealthInsurance.org, LLC.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-16px; padding-left:48px; text-indent:-24px; font-family:Symbol" align=justify>&#183;</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The return on investments of the Company was 5.4% for both 2007 and 2006.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B><I>Independence American Insurance Company</I></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-16px; padding-left:48px; text-indent:-24px; font-family:Symbol" align=justify>&#183;</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>In the fourth quarter of 2007, Independence American&#146;s rating by A.M. Best Company was upgraded to A- (Excellent).</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-16px; padding-left:48px; text-indent:-24px; font-family:Symbol" align=justify>&#183;</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Our 2007 results were negatively impacted by higher than expected claims from certain of Independence American's medical stop-loss programs.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-16px; padding-left:96px; text-indent:-24px; font-family:Courier New" align=justify>o</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Income (loss) before income taxes from the Medical Stop-Loss portion of the Independence American segment decreased $1.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2007 compared to the same period in 2006 primarily as a result of a $2.8 million charge in 2007 relating to the re-estimation of insurance reserves from the prior year in addition to an increase in the rate that the Company is reserving for current year business as more fully described in the Reserve Strengthening discussion under Results of Operations for the Year Ended December 31, 2007.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-16px; padding-left:48px; text-indent:-24px; font-family:Symbol" align=justify>&#183;</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The average percentage of gross medical stop-loss premiums written ceded from IHC to Independence American slightly increased to 22.7% during 2007 from 22.2% during 2006.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-16px; padding-left:48px; text-indent:-24px; font-family:Symbol" align=justify>&#183;</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Premiums earned increased 56.5% to $106.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2007 from $67.8 million for the year ended 2006, primarily due to the Company&#146;s agreement with Employers Direct Health (&#147;EDH&#148;) (see Note 18 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements) and the increase in fully insured health premiums assumed from IHC.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-16px; padding-left:48px; text-indent:-24px; font-family:Symbol" align=justify>&#183;</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>For the year ended December 31, 2007, Independence American wrote $5.0 million of medical stop-loss business and $21.5 million of small-group major medical business pursuant to the agreement with the aforementioned production source. &nbsp;For the year ended December 31, 2006, Independence American </P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="line-height:13pt; margin:0px; font-family:Arial; font-size:11pt">17</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:48px; font-family:Arial; page-break-before:always" align=justify>wrote $0.3 million of medical stop-loss business and $0 of small-group major medical business under the same agreement.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-16px; padding-left:48px; text-indent:-24px; font-family:Symbol" align=justify>&#183;</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Independence American added three additional licenses in 2007, bringing its total to 46 states and the District of Columbia.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-16px; padding-left:48px; text-indent:-24px; font-family:Symbol" align=justify>&#183;</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>In 2007, Independence American began writing health plans for individuals and families through a national, career agent marketing organization.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-16px; padding-left:48px; text-indent:-24px; font-family:Symbol" align=justify>&#183;</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Underwriting experience, as indicated by its GAAP Combined Ratios on the three lines of business within the Independence American segment, are as follows:</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-16px; padding-left:144px; text-indent:-24px; font-family:Wingdings" align=justify>&#167;</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:144px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Medical Stop Loss</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<TABLE style="font-size:10pt" cellspacing=0><TR height=0 style="font-size:0; display:none"><TD width=258></TD><TD width=18></TD><TD width=18></TD><TD width=72></TD><TD width=18></TD><TD width=18></TD><TD width=72></TD></TR>

</TD><TD valign=bottom width=18><P>&nbsp;</P></TD><TD valign=bottom width=18><P>&nbsp;</P></TD><TD style="border-bottom:1px solid #000000" valign=bottom width=72><P style="line-height:11pt; margin:0px; font-family:Arial; font-size:9pt" align=center><B>2006</B></P>
</TD></TR>
<TR><TD valign=top width=258><P>&nbsp;</P></TD><TD valign=top width=18><P>&nbsp;</P></TD><TD valign=top width=18><P>&nbsp;</P></TD><TD valign=bottom width=180 colspan=4><P style="line-height:11pt; margin:0px; font-family:Arial; font-size:9pt" align=center>(in thousands)</P>

</TD><TD valign=bottom width=18><P>&nbsp;</P></TD><TD valign=bottom width=18><P>&nbsp;</P></TD><TD style="border-bottom:3px double #000000" valign=bottom width=72><P style="line-height:11pt; margin:0px; padding-left:-7.2px; font-family:Arial; font-size:9pt" align=right>84.0%</P>
</TD></TR>
</TABLE>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:10pt; margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-13.333px; padding-left:96px; text-indent:-24px; font-family:Arial; font-size:8pt" align=justify>(A)</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Loss ratio represents insurance benefits claims and reserves divided by premiums earned.</P>
<P style="line-height:10pt; margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-13.333px; padding-left:96px; text-indent:-24px; font-family:Arial; font-size:8pt" align=justify>(B)</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Expense ratio represents net commissions, administrative fees, premium taxes and other underwriting expenses divided by premiums earned.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="line-height:13pt; margin:0px; font-family:Arial; font-size:11pt">18</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:10pt; margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-13.333px; padding-left:96px; text-indent:-24px; font-family:Arial; font-size:8pt; page-break-before:always" align=justify>(C)</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:96px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The combined ratio is equal to the sum of the loss ratio and the expense ratio.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B><I>MGU Subsidiaries (IndependenceCare, Marlton, RAS)</I></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-16px; padding-left:48px; text-indent:-24px; font-family:Symbol" align=justify>&#183;</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>In 2007, our MGUs wrote an aggregate of $87.2 million of annualized gross premium which generated pre-tax income of $2.0 million, as compared to $94.3 million and $1.2 million in 2006, respectively. &nbsp;Our MGUs wrote less premiums due, in part, to stricter underwriting guidelines and the continuing generally &quot;soft&quot; market. &nbsp;Pre-tax income increased primarily due to an increase in profit commissions and a decrease in operating expenses.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-16px; padding-left:48px; text-indent:-24px; font-family:Symbol" align=justify>&#183;</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>In 2007, our MGUs generated revenues of $9.8 million, as compared to $10.8 million in 2006, a decrease of 9%, due to the lower volume of premium underwritten.</P>
<P style="margin-top:13.333px; margin-bottom:0px; font-family:Arial" align=center><B>CRITICAL ACCOUNTING POLICIES</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The accounting and reporting policies of the Company conform to U.S. generally accepted accounting principles (&quot;GAAP&quot;). The preparation of the Consolidated Financial Statements in conformity with GAAP requires the Company's management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the amounts reported in the financial statements and accompanying notes. Actual results could differ from those estimates. A summary of the Company's significant accounting policies and practices is provided in Note 1 of the Notes to the Consolidated Financial Statements included in Item 8. Management has identified the accounting policies described below as those that, due to the judgments, estimates and assumptions inherent in those policies, are critical to an understanding of the Company's Consolidated Financial Statements and this Management's Discussion and Analysis.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B><I>Insurance Reserves</I></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The Company maintains loss reserves to cover its estimated liability for unpaid losses and loss adjustment expenses, where material, including legal and other fees, for reported and unreported claims incurred as of the end of each accounting period. &nbsp;These loss reserves are based on actuarial assumptions and are maintained at levels that are estimated in accordance with GAAP. &nbsp;The Company&#146;s estimate of loss reserves represents management&#146;s best estimate of the Company&#146;s liability at the balance sheet date.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:11.133px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>All of the Company&#146;s policies are short-duration and are accounted for based on actuarial estimates of the amount of loss inherent in that period&#146;s claims or open claims from prior periods, including losses incurred for claims that have not been reported (&#147;IBNR&#148;). Short-duration contract loss estimates rely on actuarial observations of ultimate loss experience for similar historical events. </P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Management believes that the Company's methods of estimating the liabilities for insurance reserves provided appropriate levels of reserves at December 31, 2007. Changes in the Company's reserve estimates are recorded through a charge or credit to its earnings.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:11.133px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:11.133px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>Medical Stop-Loss</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The Company&#146;s medical stop-loss business is comprised of employer stop-loss, HMO Reinsurance and Provider Excess. &nbsp;The two &#147;primary&#148; or &#147;key&#148; assumptions underlying the calculation of loss reserves for medical stop-loss business are (i) projected net loss ratio, and (ii) claim development patterns. &nbsp;The projected net loss ratio is set at expected levels consistent with the underlying assumptions (&#147;Projected Net Loss Ratio&#148;). Claim development patterns are set quarterly as reserve estimates are developed and are based on recent claim development history (&#147;Claim Development Patterns&#148;). &nbsp;The Company uses the Projected Net Loss Ratio to establish reserves until developing losses provide a better indication of ultimate results and it is feasible to set reserves based on Claim Development Patterns. &nbsp;The Company has concluded that a reasonably likely change in the Projected Net L
oss Ratio assumption could have a material effect on the Company&#146;s financial condition, results of operations, or liquidity (&#147;Material Effect&#148;) but a reasonably likely change in the Claim Development Pattern would not have a Material Effect.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="line-height:13pt; margin:0px; font-family:Arial; font-size:11pt">19</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; page-break-before:always" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Projected Net Loss Ratio</I></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Generally, during the first twelve months of an underwriting year, reserves for medical stop-loss are first set at the Projected Net Loss Ratio, which is determined using assumptions developed using completed prior experience trended forward. The Projected Net Loss Ratio is the Company&#146;s best estimate of future performance until such time as developing losses provide a better indication of ultimate results. &nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>While the Company establishes a best estimate of the Projected Net Loss Ratio, actual experience may deviate from this estimate. &nbsp;This was the case with the 2004, 2005 and 2006 underwriting years which deviated by 11.7, 8.1 and 7.8 Net Loss Ratio points, respectively. &nbsp;After the recorded reserve increase it is reasonably likely that the actual experience will fall within a range up to five Net Loss Ratio points above or below the expected Projected Net Loss Ratio for 2007 at December 31, 2007. &nbsp;The impact of these reasonably likely changes at December 31, 2007, would be an increase in net reserves (in the case of a higher ratio) or a decrease in net reserves (in the case of a lower ratio) of up to approximately $1.4 million with a corresponding increase or decrease in the pre-tax expense for insurance benefits, claims and reserves in the 2007 Consolidated Statement of Operations.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Major factors that affect the Projected Net Loss Ratio assumption in reserving for medical stop-loss relate to: (i) frequency and severity of claims; (ii) changes in medical trend resulting from the influences of underlying cost inflation, changes in utilization and demand for medical services, the impact of new medical technology and changes in medical treatment protocols; and (iii) the adherence by the MGUs that produce and administer this business to applicable underwriting guidelines. &nbsp;Changes in these underlying factors are what determine the reasonably likely changes in the Projected Net Loss Ratio as discussed above.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Claim Development Patterns</I></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Subsequent to the first twelve months of an underwriting year, the Company&#146;s developing losses provide a better indication of ultimate losses. At this point, claims have developed to a level where Claim Development Patterns can be applied to generate reasonably reliable estimates of ultimate claim levels. &nbsp;Development factors based on historical patterns are applied to paid and reported claims to estimate fully developed claims. Claim Development Patterns are reviewed quarterly as reserve estimates are developed and are based on recent claim development history. The Company must determine whether changes in development represent true indications of emerging experience or are simply due to random claim fluctuations. </P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The Company also establishes its best estimates of claim development factors to be applied to more developed treaty year experience. &nbsp;While these factors are based on historical Claim Development Patterns, actual claim development may vary from these estimates. &nbsp;The Company does not believe that reasonably likely changes in its actual claim development patterns would have a Material Effect.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Predicting ultimate claims and estimating reserves in medical stop-loss is more complex than fully insured medical and disability business due to the &#147;excess of loss&#148; nature of these products with very high deductibles applying to specific claims on any individual claimant and in the aggregate for a given group.&nbsp; The level of these deductibles makes it more difficult to predict the amount and payment pattern of such claims. &nbsp;Fluctuations in results for specific coverage are primarily due to the severity and frequency of individual&nbsp;claims, whereas fluctuations in aggregate coverage are largely attributable to frequency of underlying claims rather than severity. Liabilities for first dollar medical reserves and disability coverages are computed using completion factors and expected loss ratios derived from actual historical premium and claim data.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:11.133px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Due to the short-term nature of medical stop-loss, redundancies or deficiencies will typically emerge during the course of the following year rather than over a number of years. &nbsp;For Employer Stop-Loss, as noted above, the Company maintains its reserves based on underlying assumptions until it determines that an adjustment is appropriate based on emerging experience from all of its MGUs for prior underwriting years. &nbsp;Reserves for HMO Reinsurance and Provider Excess are adjusted on a policy by policy basis. &nbsp;Because of the small number of HMO Reinsurance and Provider Excess policies it writes, the Company is able to evaluate each </P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:11.133px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="line-height:13pt; margin:0px; font-family:Arial; font-size:11pt">20</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:11.133px; font-family:Arial; page-break-before:always" align=justify>policy individually for potential liability by reviewing open claims with each HMO or provider group and applying completion factors using historical data.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:11.133px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>Fully Insured Health</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Reserves for fully insured medical and dental business are established using historical claim development patterns. &nbsp;Claim development by number of months elapsed from the incurred month is studied each month and development factors are calculated. &nbsp;These claim development factors are then applied to the amount of claims paid to date for each incurred month to estimate fully complete claims. &nbsp;The difference between fully complete claims and the claims paid to date is the estimated reserve. &nbsp;Total reserves are the sum of the reserves for all incurred months.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The primary assumption in the determination of fully insured health reserves is that historical claim development patterns are representative of future claim development patterns. &nbsp;Factors which may affect this assumption include changes in claim payment processing times and procedures, changes in product design, changes in time delay in submission of claims and the incidence of unusually large claims. &nbsp;The reserving analysis includes a review of claim processing statistical measures and large claim early notifications; the potential impact of any changes in these factors are minimal. &nbsp;The time delay in submission of claims tends to be stable over time and not subject to significant volatility. &nbsp;Since our analysis considered a variety of outcomes related to these factors, the Company does not believe that any reasonably likely change in these factors will have a Material Effect.</P>
<P style="margin-top:13.333px; margin-bottom:0px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B><I>Premium and MGU Fee Income Revenue Recognition </I></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Direct and assumed premiums from short-duration contracts are recognized as revenue over the period of the contracts in proportion to the amount of insurance protection provided. &nbsp;The Company records MGU fee income as policy premium payments are earned. &nbsp;Our MGUs are compensated in two ways. &nbsp;They earn fee income based on the volume of business produced, and collect profit-sharing commissions if such business exceeds certain profitability benchmarks. &nbsp;Profit-sharing commissions are accounted for beginning in the period in which the Company believes they are reasonably estimable, which is typically at the point that claims have developed to a level where Claim Development Patterns can be applied to generate reasonably reliable estimates of ultimate claim levels.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B><I>Reinsurance</I></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>In 2007, Independence American derived most of its business from pro rata quota share reinsurance treaties with Standard Security Life and Madison National Life, which are wholly owned subsidiaries of IHC. &nbsp;These treaties were entered into in 2002 and terminate on December 31, 2014, unless terminated sooner by Independence American. &nbsp;Standard Security Life and Madison National Life must cede at least 15% of their medical stop-loss business to Independence American under these treaties. &nbsp;Additionally, Standard Security Life, Madison National Life and Independence American have received regulatory approval to cede up to 30% to Independence American under most of IHC&#146;s medical stop-loss programs. For the twelve months ended December 31, 2007 and 2006, Standard Security Life and Madison National Life ceded an average of 22.7% and 22.2%, respectively, of their medical stop-loss business to Independence American. Commencin
g in July 2004, Independence American began reinsuring 20% of Standard Security Life&#146;s short-term statutory disability benefit product (&#147;DBL&#148;) business. &nbsp;In 2005, Standard Security Life and Madison National Life began ceding 10% of the majority of its fully insured health business to Independence American.</P>
<P style="margin-top:13.333px; margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>IHC provides the Company with pro rata quota share reinsurance on business written by Independence American. &nbsp;Commencing in January 2004, Independence American began ceding 30% of its Provider Excess insurance to Madison National Life. &nbsp;In January 2005, Independence American increased the amount ceded to Madison National Life to 55%. This treaty was entered into on January 1, 2004 and will remain in force for an indefinite period, unless terminated by either party as of any December 31. &nbsp;The Company is not aware of any regulatory or other restrictions on the ability of IHC to fund its obligations under agreements in which IHC reinsures such Provider Excess business. &nbsp;Any such restrictions would at this point have a minimal impact on the </P>
<P style="margin-top:13.333px; margin-bottom:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="line-height:13pt; margin:0px; font-family:Arial; font-size:11pt">21</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:13.333px; margin-bottom:0px; font-family:Arial; page-break-before:always" align=justify>Company. &nbsp;In addition, in 2007, Independence American ceded 50% of its short-term medical (&#147;STM&#148;) and major medical for individuals and families business to unrelated reinsurers.</P>
<P style="margin-top:13.333px; margin-bottom:0px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B><I>Income Taxes</I></B></P>
<P style="margin-top:13.333px; margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>In assessing the realizability of deferred tax assets, management considers<B> </B>whether it is more likely than not that some portion or all of the deferred tax assets will not be realized. The ultimate realization of deferred tax assets is dependent upon the generation of future taxable income during the period in which those temporary differences become deductible. &nbsp;Management considers the scheduled reversal of deferred tax liabilities, projected future taxable income, and tax planning strategies in making this assessment. &nbsp;Management believes that although sufficient uncertainty exists regarding the future realization of deferred tax assets, the valuation allowance has been adjusted to account for the expected utilization of net operating losses against future taxable income.</P>
<P style="margin-top:13.333px; margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The Company has net operating loss carryforwards for federal income tax purposes available to reduce future income subject to income taxes. &nbsp;The net operating loss carryforwards expire between 2019 and 2026.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>U.S. Federal and California tax laws impose substantial restrictions on the utilization of net operating loss and credit carryforwards in the event of an &quot;ownership change&quot; for tax purposes, as defined in Section 382 of the Internal Revenue Code.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B><I>Investments </I></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The Company accounts for its investments in debt and equity securities under SFAS No. 115 (&quot;SFAS 115&quot;), Accounting for Certain Investments in Debt and Equity Securities. &nbsp;The Company has classified all of its investments as available-for-sale or trading securities. &nbsp;These investments are carried at fair value based on quoted market prices with unrealized gains and losses reported in either accumulated other comprehensive income (loss) in the Consolidated Balance Sheets for available-for-sale securities or as unrealized gains or losses in the Consolidated Statements of Operations for trading securities. &nbsp;Fixed maturities and equity securities available-for-sale totaled $49.4 million and $44.9 million at December 31, 2007 and 2006, respectively. &nbsp;Premiums and discounts on debt securities purchased at other than par value are amortized and accreted, respectively, to interest income in the Consolidated Statemen
ts of Operations, using the constant yield method over the period to maturity. &nbsp;The Company also had $4.5 million and $4.0 million, on average, in trading accounts during December 31, 2007 and 2006, respectively. &nbsp;All such trading securities were liquidated at December 31, 2007 and 2006. &nbsp;Net realized gains and losses on investments are computed using the specific identification method and are reported in the Consolidated Statements of Operations.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Declines in value of securities available&#150;for-sale that are judged to be other-than-temporary are determined based on the specific identification method and are reported in the Consolidated Statements of Operations as net realized losses. &nbsp;The factors considered by management in determining when a decline is other than temporary include but are not limited to: &nbsp;the length of time and extent to which the fair value has been less than cost; the financial condition and near-term prospects of the issuer; adverse changes in ratings announced by one or more rating agencies; whether the issuer of a debt security has remained current on principal and interest payments; whether the decline in fair value appears to be issuer specific or, alternatively, a reflection of general market or industry conditions (including, in the case of fixed maturities, the effect of changes in market interest rates); and the Company's intent and abili
ty to hold the security for a period of time sufficient to allow for a recovery in fair value.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial"><B><I>Goodwill and Other Intangibles </I></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Goodwill and intangible assets with indefinite lives, which consist of licenses, are not amortized but are tested for impairment, on a reporting unit basis, at the end of the third quarter of each year, or more frequently if indicators arise. The Company defines its reporting units on a segment basis.</P>
<P style="margin-top:5.533px; margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The Company&#146;s other intangible assets consisting of broker/third party relationships are amortized over five years.</P>
<P style="margin-top:5.533px; margin-bottom:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="line-height:13pt; margin:0px; font-family:Arial; font-size:11pt">22</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:5.533px; margin-bottom:5.533px; font-family:Arial; page-break-before:always" align=justify><B><I>Discontinued Operations</I></B></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:5.533px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The Company accrued estimates of expected liabilities related to discontinued operations through its eventual discharge. The estimated remaining liabilities related to discontinued operations include contract terminations, litigation and loss from operations subsequent to September 30, 2002. The Company reviews the estimated closure costs liability on a quarterly basis to determine changes in the costs of the discontinued operations activities. &nbsp;The cash flows used in discontinued operations are presented separately in the operating activities section of the statement of cash flows; there were no cash flows associated with investing and financing activities for the years presented for discontinued operations.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="line-height:13pt; margin:0px; font-family:Arial; font-size:11pt">23</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial; page-break-before:always" align=center><B><U>RESULTS OF OPERATIONS</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>Results of Operations for the Year Ended December 31, 2007, Compared to the Year Ended December 31, 2006 </B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I><U>Net Income</U>.</I> &nbsp;The Company&#146;s net income decreased 22% to $1,138,000, or $.13 per share, diluted, for 2007, compared to $1,454,000, or $.17 per share, diluted, for 2006.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Information by business segment for the years ended December 31, 2007 and 2006 is as follows:</P>

</TD><TD valign=bottom width=15.733><P>&nbsp;</P></TD><TD valign=bottom width=58.667><P>&nbsp;</P></TD><TD valign=bottom width=73.133 colspan=2><P>&nbsp;</P></TD><TD valign=bottom width=66.2 colspan=2><P>&nbsp;</P></TD><TD valign=bottom width=73.333 colspan=3><P>&nbsp;</P></TD><TD valign=bottom width=66 colspan=3><P>&nbsp;</P></TD><TD valign=bottom width=80.667 colspan=3><P>&nbsp;</P></TD><TD valign=bottom width=80.667 colspan=2><P>&nbsp;</P></TD><TD valign=bottom width=80.667 colspan=4><P style="margin:0px; font-size:8pt" align=right>&nbsp;</P>
</TD></TR>
<TR><TD valign=top width=101.467 colspan=2><P style="line-height:10pt; margin:0px; font-size:8pt">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Medical stop-loss</P>

</TD><TD style="border-bottom:3px double #000000" valign=bottom width=64.933 colspan=3><P style="line-height:10pt; margin:0px; font-size:8pt" align=right>1,454&nbsp;</P>
</TD></TR>
</TABLE>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I><U>Premiums Earned</U>.</I> &nbsp;Premiums earned increased 57%, or $38,323,000, to $106,100,000 for 2007, compared to $67,777,000 for 2006. &nbsp;The Company currently has three lines of business. &nbsp;Premiums relating to medical stop-loss business were $63,483,000 and $56,179,000 for 2007 and 2006, respectively. The increase is primarily due to an increase in medical stop-loss written by Independence American as a result of the Company&#146;s agreement with EDH ($4,701,000), an increase in medical stop-loss premiums assumed by Independence </P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="line-height:13pt; margin:0px; font-family:Arial; font-size:11pt">24</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial; page-break-before:always" align=justify>American ($4,014,000), and a decrease in provider excess premiums written ($753,000). &nbsp;Premiums relating to group medical, short-term medical (&#147;STM&#148;) and individual health were $39,136,000 and $7,685,000 for 2007 and 2006, respectively. &nbsp;The increase is primarily due to production of group medical resulting from the Company&#146;s agreement with EDH ($21,510,000) and an increase in premiums assumed from IHC ($9,838,000). &nbsp;Premiums relating to DBL were $3,481,000 and $3,913,000 for 2007 and 2006, respectively. &nbsp;For 2007, Independence American assumed 10% of IHC&#146;s group medical business and STM business, 20% of IHC&#146;s DBL business and 22.7% of IHC&#146;s medical stop-loss business.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I><U>MGU Fee Income</U></I>. &nbsp;MGU fee income decreased $958,000 to $9,398,000 for 2007, compared to $10,356,000 for 2006. &nbsp;MGU fee income-administration decreased $1,097,000 to $9,141,000 for 2007, compared to $10,238,000 for 2006, as our MGUs have decreased their volume of business as a result of stricter underwriting guidelines. &nbsp;MGU fee income-profit commission increased $139,000 to $257,000 for 2007, compared to $118,000 for 2006 from certain of our MGUs that experienced loss ratios at a level that generated profit commissions. &nbsp;Profit commissions for a given year are primarily based on the performance of business written by an MGU during portions of the three preceding years. &nbsp;Therefore, profit commissions for 2007 are based on business written during portions of 2004, 2005 and 2006.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I><U>Net Investment Income</U>.</I> &nbsp;Net investment income increased $344,000 to $3,611,000 for 2007, compared to $3,267,000 for 2006 due to an increase in invested assets. &nbsp;The return on investments of the Company was 5.4% for both 2007 and 2006.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I><U>Net Realized Investment Gains (Loss)</U>.</I> &nbsp;Net realized investment gains (loss) decreased $154,000 to a loss of $(88,000) for 2007, compared to a gain of $66,000 for 2006. &nbsp;The Company's decision as to whether to sell securities is based on management&#146;s ongoing evaluation of investment opportunities and economic market conditions, thus creating fluctuations in realized gains or losses from period to period. &nbsp;Included in 2007 and 2006 is an unrealized loss of $409,000 and $96,000 respectively, representing an increase in the value of the derivative liability relating to the agreement with EDH (see Note 18 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements). &nbsp;For 2007 and 2006, there were no losses on securities whose decline in value the Company deemed to be other than temporary in nature. See Note 5 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements for additional information.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I><U>Insurance Benefits, Claims and Reserves.</U></I> &nbsp;Insurance benefits claims and reserves increased 64%, or $30,819,000, to $78,618,000 for 2007, compared to $47,799,000 for 2006. &nbsp;The increase is mainly due to an increase in the volume of group medical written by Independence American and assumed from IHC, an increase in the volume of medical stop-loss, and the $4,536,000 strengthening of medical stop-loss reserves as described below. &nbsp;The increase of $30,819,000 for 2007 is comprised of a $24,011,000 increase in group medical and STM, a $6,775,000 increase in medical stop-loss, and an increase of $33,000 relating to DBL.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>Reserve Strengthening:</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>In accordance with our reserving methodology, the Company initially establishes its medical stop-loss reserves based on its best estimate of the Projected Net Loss Ratio, which is set based on underlying assumptions developed using completed prior experience trended forward (&quot;Projected Net Loss Ratio&quot;). &nbsp;This use of projections reflects the fact that actual claims on medical stop-loss cases typically are not fully reported until after the end of the policy period. &nbsp;We use the Projected Net Loss Ratio to set reserves until developing losses provide a better indication of ultimate results and it is feasible to set reserves based on claim development patterns. &nbsp;AMIC&#146;s typical practice is to then increase or decrease claims reserves once we know the actual claims experience. &nbsp;We then review quarterly the Projected Net Loss Ratios and claim development patterns as we develop reserve estimates based on recen
t claim development history (&quot;Claim Development Patterns&quot;).</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Medical stop-loss business is excess coverage with a short duration. Predicting ultimate claims and estimating reserves in medical stop-loss is especially complicated due to the &#147;excess of loss&#148; nature of these products with very high deductibles applying to specific claims on any individual claimant and in the aggregate for a given group. &nbsp;Fluctuations in results for specific coverage are primarily due to the severity and frequency of </P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="line-height:13pt; margin:0px; font-family:Arial; font-size:11pt">25</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial; page-break-before:always" align=justify>individual claims. &nbsp;Due to the short-term nature of medical stop-loss, redundancies and deficiencies will typically emerge during the following year rather than over a number of years.</P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Consistent with our experience, the industry as a whole has succumbed to the pricing pressures caused by an unexpectedly long down cycle (or &quot;soft&quot; market) for medical stop-loss business. &nbsp;The medical stop-loss market has been &#147;soft&#148; for the past four years, including cases written in 2006 and 2007, which means that many of the Company&#146;s competitors have been willing to write business at little or no margin. &nbsp;We had been aware of these market conditions and had curtailed our growth in order to attempt to achieve higher profit margins. &nbsp;The Company believed that it had taken sufficient action to insure that business written in 2006 would produce better margins than that written in 2005 and formulated a Projected Net Loss Ratio reflecting such expectations. &nbsp;As is typical with medical stop-loss business, MGUs do have some discretion within our underwriting guidelines to make pricing concessions
 on certain cases, particularly as it relates to maintaining their core renewal business and production sources.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>In the third quarter of 2007, during our quarterly review of Claim Development Patterns, we identified a material increase in claims and reserves with respect to business written in 2006. &nbsp;Such adverse development was primarily driven by the frequency of claims relative to the business written in that year proving significantly higher than what would have been predicted by prior loss development patterns. &nbsp;This increased frequency of medical stop-loss claims was due, in part, to increased severity of primary claims. &nbsp;The Company determined that this increase in claims was an indication of a pattern of higher loss frequency. &nbsp;While claims related to business written in 2007 had not yet developed to a level where Claim Development Patterns would provide reliable estimates of ultimate claim levels, we determined that it was appropriate to re-estimate the 2007 Projected Net Loss ratio to take into account developing loss
es with respect to business written in 2006.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>As a result of these actions, we increased the Projected Net Loss Ratio on the business written in 2007 by 8% and increased the Net Loss Ratio (defined as insurance benefits, claims and reserves divided by (premiums earned less underwriting expenses)) on the business written in 2006 by 7.8%. &nbsp;This resulted in a charge of $2,778,000, before income taxes, in 2007 relating to the re-estimation of unpaid losses from the prior year and additional expense of $1,758,000 in 2007 related to the 2007 business. &nbsp;The Company recorded a Net Loss Ratio for the medical stop-loss line of 103.9% and 100.5% for the years ended December 31, 2007 and 2006 respectively. &nbsp;The Net Loss Ratio equation primarily differs from the Combined Ratio in that it subtracts out expenses from the premiums prior to dividing by the insurance benefits, claims and reserves. &nbsp;We primarily use Net Loss Ratio from a reserving standpoint and as a management to
ol to measure the profitability of each medical stop-loss program. &nbsp;The Company primarily uses Combined Ratio as an accounting measurement for reporting purposes.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I><U>Selling, General and Administrative</U></I>. &nbsp;Selling, general and administrative expenses increased $7,196,000 to<I> </I>$37,463,000 for 2007, compared to $30,267,000 for 2006. &nbsp;This increase is primarily due to higher commission expense of $7,006,000 incurred by Independence American resulting from an increase in premiums written in the medical stop-loss and fully insured health lines of business, slightly offset by minor reductions in other expenses.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I><U>Amortization and Depreciation</U>.</I> &nbsp;Amortization and depreciation expense increased $282,000 to $971,000 for 2007, compared to $689,000 for 2006. &nbsp;The increased expense primarily relates to the amortization of the intangible asset representing the value of the Company&#146;s agreement with EDH (see Note 18 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements), slightly offset by the decrease in amortization related to the value of broker/TPA relationships of our MGUs.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I><U>Minority Interest</U></I>. &nbsp;The Company recorded $215,000 for 2007 and $262,000 for 2006 of expense related to the 20% minority interest in Marlton. &nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I><U>Income Taxes.</U> &nbsp;</I>The provision for income taxes decreased $269,000 to $691,000, an effective rate of 37.8%, for 2007, compared to $960,000, an effective rate of 38.9%, for 2006. &nbsp;Net income for 2007 and 2006 includes a non-cash provision for federal income taxes of $518,000 and $778,000 respectively. &nbsp;The effective rate of 37.8% for 2007 is lower than the same period in 2006 due to a tax benefit recognized in the current year from the true-up of the September 30, 2006 tax provision to the fiscal September 30, 2006 tax return. &nbsp;For as </P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="line-height:13pt; margin:0px; font-family:Arial; font-size:11pt">26</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial; page-break-before:always" align=justify>long as AMIC utilizes its net operating loss carry forwards, it will not pay any income taxes, except for federal alternative minimum taxes and state income taxes.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I><U>Gain/Loss on Discontinued Operations.</U></I> &nbsp;Loss on discontinued operations, net of tax was $0 for 2007, compared to $54,000 for 2006. &nbsp;The loss of $54,000 for 2006 was a result of unanticipated property taxes relating to Intellicom. &nbsp;For 2007, the Company has accrued for future property taxes relating to Intellicom.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=center><B>LIQUIDITY AND CAPITAL RESOURCES</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I><U>Independence American</U></I></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Independence American principally derives cash flow from: (i) operations; (ii) the receipt of scheduled principal payments on its portfolio of fixed income securities; and (iii) earnings on investments and other investing activities. &nbsp;Such cash flow is partially used to finance liabilities for insurance policy benefits and reinsurance obligations.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Independence American maintains a $5,000,000 credit facility with a financial institution to support the issuance of standby letters of credit in connection with Independence American&#146;s ordinary course of business. &nbsp;This credit facility has never been drawn upon and there are no outstanding standby letters of credit under the facility. &nbsp;The facility terminates on December 28, 2009, although, to the extent no standby letters of credit are outstanding, it may be reduced or cancelled by Independence American at any time.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I><U>Corporate</U></I></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Corporate derives cash flow funds principally from dividends and tax payments from its subsidiaries and investment income from corporate liquidity. &nbsp;There are no regulatory constraints on our MGUs&#146; ability to dividend to the parent company, however, state insurance laws have provisions relating to the ability of the parent company to use cash generated by Independence American. &nbsp;For the twelve months ended December 31, 2007, our MGUs paid $1,733,000 in dividends to Corporate.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Pursuant to the terms of a put/call arrangement entered into at the time of acquisition, the Company expects to acquire the remaining 20% interest in Marlton at the end of March 2008.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I><U>Cash Flows</U></I></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>As of December 31, 2007, the Company had $67,350,000 of cash, cash equivalents, and investments net of amounts due to/from brokers compared with $59,155,000 as of December 31, 2006.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Net cash provided by operating activities of continuing operations for the year ended December 31, 2007 was $8,574,000. &nbsp;Net cash flows were the result of insurance revenues and fees from our MGUs, partially offset by higher than expected claims and losses.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Net cash used by investing activities of continuing operations for year ended December 31, 2007 was $4,311,000. &nbsp;This results from purchases of fixed maturities and equity securities net of sales of all such securities.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Net cash provided by financing activities for the year ended December 31, 2007 was $237,000, resulting from the exercise of common stock options.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>At December 31, 2007, the Company had $15,201,000 of restricted cash at our MGUs. &nbsp;The amount at our MGUs is directly offset by corresponding liabilities for Premium and Claim Funds Payable of $15,201,000. This asset, in part, represents the premium that is remitted by the insureds and is collected by our MGUs on behalf of the insurance carriers they represent. &nbsp;Each month the premium is remitted to the insurance carriers by our MGUs. &nbsp;Until such remittance is made the collected premium is carried as an asset on the balance sheet of each of our MGUs with a corresponding payable to each insurance carrier. &nbsp;In addition to the premium being </P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="line-height:13pt; margin:0px; font-family:Arial; font-size:11pt">27</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial; page-break-before:always" align=justify>held at our MGUs, our MGUs are in possession of cash to pay claims &#147;Claim Funds&#148;. &nbsp;The cash is deposited by each insurance carrier into a bank account that our MGUs can access. &nbsp;The cash is used by our MGUs to pay claims on behalf of the insurance carriers they represent. &nbsp;The availability of cash enables our MGUs to reimburse claims in a timely manner.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The Company has $32,311,000 of insurance reserves that it expects to pay out of current assets and cash flows from future business. &nbsp;If necessary, the Company could sell its fixed maturity investments if the timing of claim payments associated with our insurance resources does not coincide with future cash flows.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The Company believes it has sufficient cash to meet its currently anticipated business requirements over the next twelve months including the funding of discontinued operations, working capital requirements, and capital investments. The Company expects continued cash usage similar to the amount used in 2007 for its discontinued operations, which are primarily lease obligations, for the year ending December 31, 2008.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>Asset Quality</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:5.533px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The nature and quality of insurance company investments must comply with all applicable insurance statutes and regulations which have been promulgated primarily for the protection of policyholders. &nbsp;Of the aggregate carrying value of the Company's cash and investments, approximately 93.9% was invested in investment grade fixed income securities, securities purchased under resale agreements, and cash and cash equivalents at December 31, 2007. &nbsp;Also at such date, 99.7% of the Company's fixed maturities were investment grade. &nbsp;These investments carry less default risk and, therefore, lower interest rates than other types of fixed maturity investments. &nbsp;At December 31, 2007, 0.3% of the carrying value of fixed maturities was invested in non-investment grade fixed income securities. &nbsp;&nbsp;Investments in such securities have different risks than investment grade securities, including greate
r risk of loss upon default, and thinner trading markets. &nbsp;The Company does not have any non-performing fixed maturities. &nbsp;At December 31, 2007, the Company had $1.6 million invested in whole loan CMOs backed by Alt-A mortgages, all of which were rated AAA. &nbsp;Of this amount, 79.0% were in CMOs that originated in 2005 or earlier and 21.0% were in CMOs that originated in 2006. &nbsp;The Company's mortgage security portfolio has no exposure to sub-prime mortgages. &nbsp;The decline in market value for the equity securities was primarily due to wider spreads for preferred stocks issued by financial institutions following the disruption in credit markets in late 2007.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:5.533px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The composition of the Company's fixed maturities at December 31, 2007, utilizing Standard and Poor's rating categories, was as follows:</P>
