</TD></TR>
</TABLE>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial"><B>Investment Impairments</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:51.333px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The Company reviews its investments regularly and monitors its investments continually for impairments. For the years ended December 31, 2007 and 2006, the Company had no realized losses for other than temporary impairments. &nbsp;The Company's gross unrealized losses on fixed maturities totaled $1,002,000 and $1,172,000 at December 31, 2007 and 2006 respectively. &nbsp;Substantially all of these securities were investment grade. The unrealized losses have been evaluated in accordance with the Company's policy and were determined to be temporary in nature at December 31, 2007. The Company holds all fixed maturities as available-for-sale and accordingly marks all of its securities to market through accumulated other comprehensive income (loss).</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="line-height:13pt; margin:0px; font-family:Arial; font-size:11pt">28</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial; page-break-before:always" align=justify><B><U>Balance Sheet</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Total investments increased $3,851,000 to $61,066,000 at December 31, 2007 from $57,215,000 at December 31, 2006, due to income from continuing operations before income tax and the timing of insurance liabilities. &nbsp;The $1,593,000 increase in total stockholders' equity is primarily due to net income of $1,138,000 generated during 2007, and the exercise of stock options.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The Company had receivables from reinsurers of $10,845,000 at December 31, 2007. &nbsp;Substantially all of the business ceded to such reinsurers is of short duration. &nbsp;All of such receivables are either due from related parties, highly rated companies or are adequately secured. &nbsp;No allowance for doubtful accounts was deemed necessary at December 31, 2007.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial" align=center><B><U>CAPITAL RESOURCES</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Due to its strong capital ratio and excellent asset quality and credit-worthiness, the Company remains well positioned to increase or diversify its current activities. It is anticipated that future acquisitions or other expansion of operations will be funded internally from existing capital and surplus and parent company liquidity. In the event additional funds are required, it is expected that they would be borrowed or raised in the public or private capital markets to the extent determined to be necessary or desirable.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>In accordance with SFAS No. 115, the Company may carry its portfolio of fixed income securities either as held to maturity (carried at amortized cost), as trading securities (carried at fair value) or as available-for-sale (carried at fair value). &nbsp;The Company has chosen to carry its fixed maturity securities as available-for-sale. &nbsp;The Company experienced a change in net unrealized loss of $13,000 reflecting a net unrealized loss of $1,204,000 at December 31, 2007 from a net unrealized loss of $1,191,000 at December 31, 2006. &nbsp;From time to time, as warranted, the Company employs investment strategies to mitigate interest rate and other market exposures.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial" align=center><B><U>OUTLOOK</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>Independence American</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Independence American, which is domiciled in Delaware, is licensed to write property and/or casualty insurance in 46 states and the District of Columbia, and has an A- (Excellent) rating from A.M. Best Company, Inc. (&quot;A.M. Best&quot;). An A.M. Best rating is assigned after an extensive quantitative and qualitative evaluation of a company's financial condition and operating performance, and is also based upon factors relevant to policyholders, agents, and intermediaries, and is not directed towards protection of investors. A.M. Best ratings are not recommendations to buy, sell or hold securities of the Company.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Since its acquisition by AMIC in 2002, Independence American&#146;s primary source of revenue has been reinsurance premiums. &nbsp;The majority of these premiums are ceded to Independence American from pro rata quota share loss reinsurance treaties (the &#147;IHC Treaties&#148;) with Standard Security Life and Madison National Life, which are wholly owned subsidiaries of Independence Holding Company (&#147;IHC&#148;). &nbsp;IHC currently owns 49.7% of the Company&#146;s common stock. &nbsp;The IHC Treaties were entered into in 2002 and terminate on December 31, 2014, unless terminated sooner by Independence American. &nbsp;There are three factors that determine the amount of premiums assumed by Independence American: (i) the percentage of business ceded to Independence American pursuant to the IHC Treaties or otherwise; (ii) the amount of gross premium produced by the MGUs and other distribution sources written by Standard Security Life
 or Madison National Life that is ceded to Independence American under the IHC Treaties; and (iii) the amount of gross premium produced by the MGUs and other distribution sources written by carriers other than Standard Security Life or Madison National Life that is ceded to Independence American. &nbsp;With respect to the IHC Treaties, Independence American assumes medical stop-loss, fully insured health and short-term statutory disability benefit (DBL) premiums from IHC. &nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>In 2007, Independence American began writing small-group major medical, medical stop-loss, major medical plans for individuals and families, and short-term medical. Given its enhanced A- (Excellent) rating from A.M. Best, Independence American expects to expand the distribution of its medical stop-loss products through </P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="line-height:13pt; margin:0px; font-family:Arial; font-size:11pt">29</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial; page-break-before:always" align=justify>our MGUs, and increase meaningfully the business written on its paper, especially major medical plans for individuals and families.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B><U>IHC Treaties</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>With respect to the IHC Treaties, the Company&#146;s operating results are affected by the following factors: (i) the percentage of business ceded to Independence American pursuant to the IHC Treaties; (ii) the amount of gross premium written by Standard Security Life and Madison National Life that can be ceded pursuant to the IHC Treaties; and (iii) the profitability of the business ceded.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>Percentage of Business Ceded</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>In 2008 and beyond, the percentage of medical stop-loss ceded to Independence American will depend on how much IHC determines it has available to reinsure and Independence American&#146;s desire to reinsure IHC&#146;s business. &nbsp;Since the percentage being ceded is now well in excess of the contractual minimum, there is no guaranty that IHC will continue to increase the percentage of business ceded to Independence American or, in fact, cede in excess of 15%. &nbsp;However, our MGUs are the largest producers of medical stop-loss business for IHC, controlling a majority of this premium in 2007.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Commencing in July 2004, Independence American began reinsuring 20% of Standard Security Life&#146;s short-term statutory disability benefit product (&#147;DBL&#148;). &nbsp;Standard Security Life is not contractually obligated to continue to cede this business to Independence American after termination of the current treaty year. &nbsp;In 2005, Standard Security Life and Madison National Life began ceding 10% of the majority of its fully insured health business to Independence American. &nbsp;Standard Security Life and Madison National Life are not contractually obligated to continue to cede this business to Independence American after termination of the current treaty years. &nbsp;The Company does not expect the percentage ceded to it from IHC will change significantly in the next twelve months</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Upon renewal of each of the programs underlying the IHC Treaties, Standard Security Life and Madison National Life determine the maximum percentage of risk to be offered to Independence American and Independence American determines the percentage that it wishes to accept. A typical pro rata quota share reinsurance treaty is for a twelve month period in which the ceding company and the reinsurer share the premiums as well as the losses and expenses in an agreed proportion for all policies written with an effective date within this period. &nbsp;Most treaties run from January 1 to December 31, but others could begin and end in other periods. &nbsp;Therefore the percentage ceded could change as the year progresses. &nbsp;If Independence American, Standard Security Life, and Madison National Life had agreed to increase the average percentage ceded to Independence American by 1% (from the 22.7% ceded for the twelve months ended December 31, 
2007) and Standard Security Life&#146;s and Madison National Life&#146;s gross written premium had remained unchanged, Independence American&#146;s premium would have increased by approximately $1.9 million, which is approximately 1.8% of total net premiums earned for the year ended December 31, 2007. &nbsp;That increase in premium, however, would not have flowed directly to pre-tax operating income because of corresponding changes in insurance benefits, claims and reserves and other expenses attributable to the increase in premiums.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>Amount of Gross Premiums Written</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The gross medical stop-loss premiums written by IHC decreased in 2007 by 5.1% and such premiums produced by our MGUs decreased by 5.3% in 2007 as a result of writing and/or renewing fewer policies due to competitors' willingness to write business at profit margins lower than those acceptable to the Company, partially offset by increased rates on the policies retained. &nbsp;This resulted in a decrease in the gross amount of premium available to be ceded to Independence American. &nbsp;Our MGUs do not anticipate materially increasing their production of medical stop-loss business in 2008. &nbsp;IHC has reported that it expects its gross DBL premiums to decrease slightly in 2008.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="line-height:13pt; margin:0px; font-family:Arial; font-size:11pt">30</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial; page-break-before:always" align=justify><B>Profitability</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The medical stop-loss market is generally cyclical in nature. When a product experiences several consecutive years of underwriting profitability, it is not unusual for there to be more competitors entering that line which can increase pressure on pricing and create a &#147;softer&#148; market. The medical stop-loss market began to &#147;soften&#148; in 2003 and less favorable conditions continued through 2007. &nbsp;As a result of these market conditions, the rate that the carriers that cede business to the Company were able to charge for medical stop-loss increased at a lesser rate in recent years, however, increases in medical trend have also been held in check to a greater extent and deductibles and attachment points have increased. This reduces the risk taker&#146;s overall risk exposure. &nbsp;Fully insured health business tends to be less volatile and less cyclical than excess insurance.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Therefore, the impact on the Company&#146;s operating results relating to the IHC Treaties can be summarized as follows: (i) assuming the underlying business is profitable, the Company&#146;s results would be positively impacted if IHC were to cede a higher percentage and adversely affected if IHC were to cede less; (ii) Independence American&#146;s income would be negatively impacted if IHC&#146;s gross premium written were to decrease, &nbsp;and (iii) Independence American&#146;s income in future years would be positively affected if IHC were to produce higher profit margins, and negatively impacted if loss ratios increase.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B><U>Marketing Agreements</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>In February 2006, Independence American entered into an agreement with a marketing organization with a block of fully insured health business, including CDHPs, primarily sold to small employer groups, and medical stop-loss, to begin writing for Independence American. &nbsp;The organization that produces this business began writing employer medical stop-loss through Independence American in 2006, and moved the majority of its existing block of fully insured and stop-loss health insurance to Independence American during 2007. &nbsp;Independence American will be the exclusive issuing carrier for business underwritten by this organization through December 31, 2011. &nbsp;Subject to certain conditions, the agreement will automatically extend until December 31, 2016, and this organization could be entitled to additional cash consideration (see Note 18 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements).</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>In addition, the Company has entered into an agreement with a national, career agent marketing organization to begin marketing health plans to individuals and families utilizing Independence American as the carrier. &nbsp;Independence American retains 50% of the risk on this business. &nbsp;Gross premiums of $231,000 were written under this program in 2007. &nbsp;The program will be administered by Insurers Administrative Corporation, a wholly owned subsidiary of IHC.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-16px; padding-left:-7.333px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>Item 7A.</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:-7.333px; text-indent:66px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>&nbsp;<I>Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures About Market Risk</I></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>Not applicable</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:13.333px; margin-bottom:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="line-height:13pt; margin:0px; font-family:Arial; font-size:11pt">31</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>

<P style="margin-top:13.333px; margin-bottom:0px; font-family:Arial" align=center><B><I>AMERICAN INDEPENDENCE CORP. AND SUBSIDIARIES</I></B></P>

<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>

<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="line-height:13pt; margin:0px; font-family:Arial; font-size:11pt">32</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial; page-break-before:always" align=center>&nbsp;<B><U>Report of Management on Internal Control Over Financial Reporting</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial"><B>The Board of Directors and Stockholders</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial"><B>American Independence Corp.</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The management of American Independence Corp. (&quot;AMIC&quot;) is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting. AMIC's internal control system was designed to provide reasonable assurance to the Company's management and Board of Directors regarding reliability of financial reporting and the preparation and fair presentation of published financial statements for external purposes in accordance with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>All internal control systems, no matter how well designed, have inherent limitations. Therefore, even those systems determined to be effective can provide only reasonable assurance with respect to financial statement preparation and presentation. &nbsp;Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Management assessed the effectiveness of AMIC's internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2007. In making this assessment, management used the criteria set forth by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (COSO) in <I>Internal Control &#150;Integrated Framework</I>. Based on our assessment we concluded that, as of December 31, 2007, AMIC's internal control over financial reporting is effective.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="line-height:13pt; margin:0px; font-family:Arial; font-size:11pt">33</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; page-break-before:always" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:14.467px; font-family:Arial" align=center><B><U>&nbsp;Report of Independent Registered Public Accounting Firm</U></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial"><B>The Board of Directors and Stockholders</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial"><B>American Independence Corp.:</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:6.667px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>We have audited the accompanying consolidated balance sheets of American Independence Corp. and subsidiaries (the &#147;Company&#148;) as of December 31, 2007 and 2006, and the related consolidated statements of operations, stockholders&#146; equity, and cash flows for the years then ended. &nbsp;In connection with our audits of the consolidated financial statements, we have also audited the financial statement schedules listed in the accompanying index. &nbsp;These consolidated financial statements and financial statement schedules are the responsibility of the Company&#146;s management. Our responsibility is to express an opinion on these consolidated financial statements and financial statement schedules based on our audits.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:6.667px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>We conducted our audits in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States). &nbsp;Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements are free of material misstatement. &nbsp;The Company is not required to have, nor were we engaged to perform, an audit of its internal control over financial reporting as a basis for designing audit procedures that are appropriate in the circumstances, but not for the purpose of expressing an opinion of the effectiveness of the Company&#146;s internal control over financial reporting. &nbsp;Accordingly, we express no such opinion in 2007. &nbsp;An audit also includes examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in the financial statements, assessing the accounting principles used and significant estimates made by management, a
s well as evaluating the overall financial statement presentation. &nbsp;We believe that our audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinion.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:6.667px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>In our opinion, the consolidated financial statements referred to above present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position of American Independence Corp. and subsidiaries as of December 31, 2007 and 2006, and the results of their operations and their cash flows for the years then ended, in conformity with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles. &nbsp;Also in our opinion, the related financial statement schedules, when considered in relation to the basic consolidated financial statements taken as a whole, present fairly, in all material respects, the information set forth therein.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:6.667px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:6.667px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:6.667px; font-family:Arial">/s/ KPMG LLP</P>

</TD><TD valign=top width=22><P>&nbsp;</P></TD><TD valign=top width=95.333><P>&nbsp;</P></TD><TD valign=top width=22><P>&nbsp;</P></TD><TD valign=top width=22><P>&nbsp;</P></TD><TD valign=top width=88><P>&nbsp;</P></TD></TR>

<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR>
<BR></P>
<P style="line-height:13pt; margin:0px; font-family:Arial; font-size:11pt">38</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
</DIV><DIV style="width:586px"><P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial; page-break-before:always" align=center><B>American Independence Corp. and Subsidiaries</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial" align=center><B>Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-16px; padding-left:24px; text-indent:-24px; font-family:Arial"><B>1.</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:24px; font-family:Arial"><B>Nature of Business</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>American Independence Corp. (&quot;AMIC&quot; or &quot;the Company&quot;) is a holding company engaged in the insurance and reinsurance business through: a) its wholly owned insurance company, Independence American Insurance Company (&quot;Independence American&quot;); b) its managing general underwriter subsidiaries: IndependenceCare Holdings L.L.C. and its subsidiaries (collectively referred to as &quot;IndependenceCare&quot;); Risk Assessment Strategies, Inc. (&quot;RAS&quot;), and Marlton Risk Group LLC (&quot;Marlton&quot;); c) its 23% investment in Majestic Underwriters LLC (&quot;Majestic&quot;); and d) its 51% ownership in HealthInsurance.org, LLC (&#147;HIO&#148;), an insurance agency. &nbsp;IndependenceCare, RAS and Marlton are collectively referred to as &quot;our MGUs&quot;.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Prior to November 14, 2002, the Company (then known as SoftNet Systems, Inc.) was a holding company principally engaged in providing Internet services. &nbsp;All previously reported business segments have ceased operations or have been sold, and accordingly are reported as discontinued operations (see Note 8 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements).</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Since November 2002, AMIC has been affiliated with Independence Holding Company (&quot;IHC&quot;), an insurance holding company, which held 48% of AMIC&#146;s outstanding common stock at December 31, 2007. &nbsp;Subsequent to December 31, 2007, IHC acquired an additional 1.7% to bring its ownership to 49.7%. &nbsp;The senior management of IHC provides direction to the Company through a service agreement between the Company and IHC. &nbsp;IHC has also entered into long-term reinsurance treaties to cede medical stop-loss to the Company. &nbsp;Additionally, the Company reinsures IHC&#146;s New York statutory disability business, IHC&#146;s short-term medical (&#147;STM&#148;) business and group major medical business.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-16px; padding-left:24px; text-indent:-24px; font-family:Arial"><B>2.</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:24px; font-family:Arial"><B>Summary of Significant Accounting Policies</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial"><B><I>Principles of Consolidation and Presentation of Financial Statements</I></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The consolidated financial statements have been prepared in conformity with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles and include the accounts of AMIC and its consolidated subsidiaries. All intercompany transactions have been eliminated in consolidation. The preparation of financial statements in conformity with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect: &nbsp;(i) the reported amounts of assets and liabilities; (ii) the disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements; and (iii) the reported amounts of revenues and expenses during the reporting period. Actual results could differ from those estimates.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial"><B><I>Reclassifications</I></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Certain reclassifications have been made to prior years' consolidated financial statements and related notes to the consolidated financial statements in order to conform to the current year presentation.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B><I>Investment in</I></B><I> </I><B><I>Majestic Underwriters LLC</I></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:61.067px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The Company's investment in Majestic Underwriters LLC (see Note 6 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements) is carried on the equity method with the Company's share of income or loss credited or charged, as appropriate, to net investment income in the Consolidated Statement of Operations with a corresponding charge to the Company's investment account. The </P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
</DIV><DIV style="width:666.267px"><P style="line-height:13pt; margin:0px; font-family:Arial; font-size:11pt">39</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
</DIV><DIV style="width:586px"><P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial; page-break-before:always" align=justify>Company also reduces its investment account for its proportionate share of the amortization expense for the intangible assets recorded in the acquisition.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial"><B><I>Goodwill and Other Intangibles</I></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Goodwill and intangible assets with indefinite lives, which consist of licenses, are not amortized but are tested for impairment, on a reporting unit basis, at the end of the third quarter of each year, or more frequently if indicators arise. &nbsp;The Company defines its reporting units on a segment basis.</P>
<P style="margin-top:5.533px; margin-bottom:5.533px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>For goodwill, if the book value of a reporting unit exceeds its fair value, the implied fair value of goodwill is compared with the carrying amount of goodwill. If the carrying amount of goodwill exceeds the implied fair value, an impairment loss is recorded in an amount equal to that excess.</P>
<P style="margin-top:13.333px; margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The Company's intangible assets with definite lives, consisting of broker/third party relationships and marketing agreements, are amortized over the expected life of the assets (see Note 4 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements).</P>
<P style="margin-top:13.333px; margin-bottom:0px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B><I>Fair Value of Financial Instruments</I></B></P>
<P style="margin-top:13.333px; margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The carrying amount of cash and cash equivalents, restricted cash, short-term investments, due from reinsurers and premiums receivable approximates their fair values.</P>
<P style="margin-top:13.333px; margin-bottom:0px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B><I>Cash, Cash Equivalents and Restricted Cash</I></B></P>
<P style="margin-top:13.333px; margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Cash and cash equivalents consist of cash and highly liquid securities with maturities of three months or less from date of purchase. &nbsp;Restricted cash primarily consists of funds held by our MGUs for the benefit of their insurers and reinsurers. &nbsp;These funds are restricted and are to be used to facilitate expeditious payment of approved claims. &nbsp;The funds are replenished by the insurers and reinsurers as claims are paid by our MGUs.</P>
<P style="margin-top:13.333px; margin-bottom:0px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B><I>Short-Term Investments</I></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Investments with original maturities of 91-days to 1 year are considered short-term investments and are carried at cost which approximates fair value.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B><I>Securities Purchased Under Agreements to Resell and Securities Sold Under Agreements to Repurchase</I></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Securities purchased under agreements to resell (&quot;resale agreements&quot;) and securities sold under agreements to repurchase (&quot;repurchase agreements&quot;) are carried at the amounts at which the securities will be subsequently resold or repurchased as specified in the agreements.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B><I>Investment Securities</I></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>(i)</B> Investments in fixed income securities, redeemable preferred stock equity securities and derivatives (options and options on future contracts) are accounted for as follows:</P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:96px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>(a)</B> Securities which are held for trading purposes are carried at estimated fair value (&quot;fair value&quot;). &nbsp;Changes in fair value are credited or charged, as appropriate, to <A NAME="OLE_LINK4"></A>net realized investment gains in the Consolidated Statements of Operations.</P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:96px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>(b)</B> Securities not held for trading purposes which may or may not be held to maturity (&quot;available-for-sale securities&quot;) are carried at fair value. Unrealized gains and losses </P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
</DIV><DIV style="width:666.267px"><P style="line-height:13pt; margin:0px; font-family:Arial; font-size:11pt">40</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
</DIV><DIV style="width:586px"><P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial; page-break-before:always" align=justify>deemed temporary are credited or charged, as appropriate, directly to accumulated other comprehensive income (a component of stockholders' equity). &nbsp;Premiums and discounts on debt securities purchased at other than par value are amortized and accreted, respectively, to interest income in the Consolidated Statements of Operations, using the constant yield method over the period to maturity. &nbsp;Realized gains and losses on sales of available-for-sale securities, and unrealized losses considered to be other than temporary, are credited or charged to net realized investment gains in the Consolidated Statements of Operations.</P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>(ii)</B> Financial instruments sold, but not yet purchased, represent obligations to replace borrowed securities that have been sold. &nbsp;Such transactions occur in anticipation of declines in the fair value of the securities. The Company's risk is an increase in the fair value of the securities sold in excess of the consideration received, but that risk is mitigated as a result of relationships to certain securities owned. &nbsp;Unrealized gains or losses on open transactions are credited or charged, as appropriate, to net realized investment gains in the Consolidated Statements of Operations. &nbsp;While the transaction is open, the Company will also incur an expense for any accrued dividends or interest payable to the lender of the securities. &nbsp;When the transaction is closed, the Company realizes a gain or loss in an amount equal to the difference between the price at which the securities were sold and the cost of replacing
 the borrowed securities. &nbsp;There were no such transactions outstanding at December 31, 2007 and 2006.</P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>(iii)</B> Realized gains or losses on sales of securities are determined on the basis of specific identification.</P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>(iv)</B> The Company enters into derivative transactions, such as put and call option contracts and options on interest rate futures contracts, to minimize losses on portions of the Company's fixed income portfolio in a rapidly changing interest rate environment. &nbsp;Equity index options are entered into to offset price fluctuations in the equity markets. These derivative financial instruments are all readily marketable and are carried on the Consolidated Balance Sheets at their current fair value with changes in fair value (unrealized gains or losses), credited or charged, as appropriate, to net realized investment gains in the Consolidated Statements of Operations. All realized gains and losses are reflected currently in the Consolidated Statements of Operations. &nbsp;Losses on these instruments were $480,000 and $19,000 during 2007 and 2006, respectively. &nbsp;There were no such derivative transactions outstanding at December 
31, 2007 and 2006.</P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>(v) </B>Fair value is determined by quoted market prices, where available, or by independent pricing services.</P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>(vi) </B>The Company reviews its investment securities regularly and determines whether other than temporary impairments have occurred. If a decline in fair value is judged by management to be other than temporary, a loss is recognized by a charge to the Consolidated Statements of Operations, establishing a new cost basis for the security. The factors considered by management in its regular review include, but are not limited to: &nbsp;the length of time and extent to which the fair value has been less than cost; the financial condition and near-term prospects of the issuer; adverse changes in ratings announced by one or more rating agencies; whether the issuer of a debt security has remained current on principal and interest payments; whether the decline in fair value appears to be issuer specific or, alternatively, a reflection of general market or industry conditions (including, in the case of fixed maturities, the effect of chang
es in market interest rates); and the Company's intent and ability to hold the security for a period of time sufficient to allow for a recovery in fair value. &nbsp;For securities within the scope of Emerging Issues Task Force Issue 99-20, such as purchased interest-only securities, an impairment loss is recognized when there has been a decrease in expected cash flows combined with a decline in the security's fair value below cost.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B><I>Fixed Assets</I></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Fixed assets are stated at cost net of accumulated depreciation. &nbsp;Improvements are capitalized, while repair and maintenance costs are charged to operations as incurred. &nbsp;Depreciation of property and equipment has been provided on the straight-line method over the estimated useful lives of the respective assets (3 years for computer equipment and 7 years for </P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
</DIV><DIV style="width:666.267px"><P style="line-height:13pt; margin:0px; font-family:Arial; font-size:11pt">41</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
</DIV><DIV style="width:586px"><P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial; page-break-before:always" align=justify>furniture and fixtures). &nbsp;Amortization of leasehold improvements has been provided on the straight-line method over the shorter of the lease term or the estimated useful life of the asset.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B><I>Premium and MGU Fee Income Revenue Recognition</I></B></P>
<P style="margin-top:13.333px; margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Direct and assumed premiums from short-duration contracts are recognized as revenue over the period of the contracts in proportion to the amount of insurance protection provided. &nbsp;The Company records MGU fee income as policy premium payments are earned. &nbsp;Our MGUs are compensated in two ways. &nbsp;They earn fee income based on the volume of business produced, and collect profit-sharing commissions if such business exceeds certain profitability benchmarks. Profit-sharing commissions are accounted for beginning in the period in which the Company believes they are reasonably estimable, which is typically at the point that claims have developed to a level where Claim Development Patterns can be applied to generate reasonably reliable estimates of ultimate claim levels. Profit-sharing commissions are a function of an MGU attaining certain profitability thresholds and could greatly vary from quarter to qu
arter.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>MGU fee income consisted of the following:</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<TABLE style="font-size:10pt" cellspacing=0 align=center><TR height=0 style="font-size:0; display:none"><TD width=240.533></TD><TD width=15.733></TD><TD width=23.867></TD><TD width=61></TD><TD width=15.733></TD><TD width=22></TD><TD width=73.333></TD></TR>

</TD><TD valign=bottom width=15.733><P>&nbsp;</P></TD><TD valign=bottom width=22><P style="margin-top:5.533px; margin-bottom:5.533px; font-family:Arial" align=right>$</P>
</TD><TD style="border-bottom:3px double #000000" valign=bottom width=73.333><P style="margin-top:5.533px; margin-bottom:5.533px; font-family:Arial" align=right>10,356</P>
</TD></TR>
<TR><TD valign=top width=240.533><P>&nbsp;</P></TD><TD valign=top width=15.733><P>&nbsp;</P></TD><TD valign=top width=23.867><P>&nbsp;</P></TD><TD valign=top width=61><P>&nbsp;</P></TD><TD valign=top width=15.733><P>&nbsp;</P></TD><TD valign=top width=22><P>&nbsp;</P></TD><TD valign=top width=73.333><P>&nbsp;</P></TD></TR>
</TABLE>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B><I>Insurance Reserves </I></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The Company maintains loss reserves to cover its estimated liability for unpaid losses and loss adjustment expenses, where material, including legal and other fees and a portion of the Company's general expenses, for reported and unreported claims incurred as of the end of each accounting period. &nbsp;These loss reserves are based on actuarial assumptions and are maintained at levels that are in accordance with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles. &nbsp;Many factors could affect these reserves, including economic and social conditions, frequency and severity of claims, medical trend resulting from the influences of underlying cost inflation, changes in utilization and demand for medical services, and changes in doctrines of legal liability and damage awards in litigation. &nbsp;Therefore, the Company's reserves are necessarily based on estimates, assumptions and analysis of historical experience. &nbsp;The Company's results d
epend upon the variation between actual claims experience and the assumptions used in determining reserves and pricing products. Reserve assumptions and estimates require significant judgment and, therefore, are inherently uncertain. &nbsp;The Company cannot determine with precision the ultimate amounts that will be paid for actual claims or the timing of those payments. &nbsp;The Company's estimate of loss represents management's best estimate of the Company's liability at the balance sheet date.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>All of the Company&#146;s contracts are short-duration and are accounted for based on actuarial estimates of the amount of loss inherent in that period&#146;s claims, including losses incurred for claims that have not been reported (&#147;IBNR&#148;). Short-duration contract loss estimates rely on actuarial observations of ultimate loss experience for similar historical events. </P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
</DIV><DIV style="width:666.267px"><P style="line-height:13pt; margin:0px; font-family:Arial; font-size:11pt">42</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
</DIV><DIV style="width:586px"><P style="margin:0px; text-indent:44px; font-family:Arial; page-break-before:always" align=justify><B>Medical Stop-Loss</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:44px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Liabilities for insurance reserves on certain short-term medical coverages, such as medical stop-loss, are computed using completion factors and expected Net Loss Ratios derived from actual historical premium and claim data. &nbsp;Reserves for medical stop-loss insurance are more volatile in nature than those for fully insured medical insurance. &nbsp;This is primarily due to the excess nature of medical stop-loss, with very high deductibles applying to specific claims on any individual claimant and in the aggregate for a given group. &nbsp;The level of these deductibles makes it more difficult to predict the amount and payment pattern of such claims. &nbsp;Furthermore, these excess claims are highly sensitive to changes in factors such as medical trend, provider contracts and medical treatment protocols, adding to the difficulty in predicting claim values and estimating reserves. &nbsp;Also, because medical stop-loss is in excess of an
 underlying benefit plan, there is an additional layer of claim reporting and processing that can affect claim payment patterns. &nbsp;Finally, changes in the distribution of business by effective month can affect reserve estimates due to the timing of claim occurrences and the time required to accumulate claims against the stop-loss deductible.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The two &#147;primary&#148; or &#147;key&#148; assumptions underlying the calculation of loss reserves for medical stop-loss business are (i) projected net loss ratio, and (ii) claim development patterns. &nbsp;The projected net loss ratio is set at expected levels consistent with the underlying assumptions (&#147;Projected Net Loss Ratio&#148;). Claim development patterns are set quarterly as reserve estimates are developed and are based on recent claim development history (&#147;Claim Development Patterns&#148;). &nbsp;The Company uses the Projected Net Loss Ratio to establish reserves until developing losses provide a better indication of ultimate results and it is feasible to set reserves based on Claim Development Patterns. &nbsp;The Company has concluded that a reasonably likely change in the Projected Net Loss Ratio assumption could have a material effect on the Company&#146;s financial condition, results of operations, or liquid
ity (&#147;Material Effect&#148;) but a reasonably likely change in the Claim Development Pattern would not have a Material Effect.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Projected Net Loss Ratio</I></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Generally, during the first twelve months of an underwriting year, reserves for medical stop-loss are first set at the Projected Net Loss Ratio, which is set using assumptions developed using completed prior experience trended forward. The Projected Net Loss Ratio is the Company&#146;s best estimate of future performance until such time as developing losses provide a better indication of ultimate results. &nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Major factors that affect the Projected Net Loss Ratio assumption in reserving for medical stop-loss relate to: (i) frequency and severity of claims; (ii) changes in medical trend resulting from the influences of underlying cost inflation, changes in utilization and demand for medical services, the impact of new medical technology and changes in medical treatment protocols; and (iii) the adherence by the MGUs that produce and administer this business to the Company&#146;s underwriting guidelines.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Claim Development Patterns</I></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Subsequent to the first twelve months of an underwriting year, the Company&#146;s developing losses provide a better indication of ultimate losses. &nbsp;At this point, claims have developed to a level where Claim Development Patterns can be applied to generate reasonably reliable estimates of ultimate claim levels. &nbsp;Development factors based on historical patterns are applied to paid and reported claims to estimate fully developed claims. &nbsp;Claim Development Patterns are reviewed quarterly as reserve estimates are developed and are based on recent claim development history. &nbsp;The Company must determine whether changes in development represent true indications of emerging experience or are simply due to random claim fluctuations. </P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
</DIV><DIV style="width:666.267px"><P style="line-height:13pt; margin:0px; font-family:Arial; font-size:11pt">43</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
</DIV><DIV style="width:586px"><P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial; page-break-before:always" align=justify>The Company also establishes its best estimates of claim development factors to be applied to more developed treaty year experience. &nbsp;While these factors are based on historical Claim Development Patterns, actual claim development may vary from these estimates.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Predicting ultimate claims and estimating reserves in Medical Stop-Loss is more complex than first dollar medical and disability business due to the &#147;excess of loss&#148; nature of these products with very high deductibles applying to specific claims on any individual claimant and in the aggregate for a given group. &nbsp;The level of these deductibles makes it more difficult to predict the amount and payment pattern of such claims. &nbsp;Fluctuations in results for specific coverage are primarily due to the severity and frequency of individual claims, whereas fluctuations in aggregate coverage are largely attributable to frequency of underlying claims rather than severity. </P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Due to the short-term nature of Medical Stop-Loss, redundancies or deficiencies will typically emerge during the course of the following year rather than over a number of years. &nbsp;For Employer Stop-Loss, as noted above, the Company typically maintains its reserves based on underlying assumptions until it determines that an adjustment is appropriate based on emerging experience from all of its MGUs for prior underwriting years. &nbsp;Reserves for HMO Reinsurance and Provider Excess are adjusted on a policy by policy basis. &nbsp;Because of the small number of HMO Reinsurance and Provider Excess policies it writes or reinsures, the Company is able to evaluate each policy individually for potential liability by reviewing open claims with each HMO or provider group and applying completion factors using historical data.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:44px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>Fully Insured Health</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Liabilities for insurance reserves for fully insured medical business are established to provide for the liability for incurred but not paid claims. &nbsp;Reserves are calculated using standard actuarial methods and practices. &nbsp;Historical paid claim patterns are reviewed and estimated development factors are applied to immature incurred months to calculate these reserves. &nbsp;The primary assumption in the determination of fully insured reserves is that historical claim development patterns are representative of future claim development patterns. &nbsp;Factors which may affect this assumption include changes in claim payment processing times and procedures, changes in time delay in submission of claims and the incidence of unusually large claims. &nbsp;Liabilities for fully insured medical reserves and disability coverages are computed using completion factors and expected Net Loss Ratios derived from actual historical premium and
 claim data. &nbsp;The reserving analysis includes a review of claim processing statistical measures and large claim early notifications; the potential impacts of any changes in these factors are not material. &nbsp;The delay in submission of claims tends to be stable over time and not subject to significant volatility.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>While these calculations are based on standard methodologies, they are estimates based on historical patterns.&nbsp; To the extent that actual claim payment patterns differ from historical patterns, such estimated reserves may be redundant or inadequate. &nbsp;The effects of such deviations are evaluated by considering claim backlog statistics and reviewing the reasonableness of projected claim ratios.&nbsp; Other factors which may affect the accuracy of reserve estimates include the proportion of large claims which may take longer to adjudicate, changes in billing patterns by providers and changes in claim management practices such as hospital bill audits.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Liabilities for insurance reserves on STM and disability coverages are computed using claim development patterns and projected loss ratios derived from actual historical premium and claim data.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Management believes that the Company's methods of estimating the liabilities for insurance reserves provided appropriate levels of reserves at December 31, 2007 and December </P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
</DIV><DIV style="width:666.267px"><P style="line-height:13pt; margin:0px; font-family:Arial; font-size:11pt">44</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
</DIV><DIV style="width:586px"><P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial; page-break-before:always" align=justify>31, 2006. Changes in the Company's reserve estimates are recorded through a charge or credit to its earnings in the period in which they arise.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B><I>Reinsurance</I></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Amounts recoverable or paid for under reinsurance contracts are included in total assets or total liabilities as due from reinsurers or due to reinsurers.</P>
<P style="margin-top:13.333px; margin-bottom:0px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B><I>Income Taxes</I></B></P>
<P style="margin-top:13.333px; margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The Company accounts for income taxes under the asset and liability method<I>.</I> Deferred tax assets and liabilities are recognized for the future tax consequences attributable to differences between the financial carrying amounts of existing assets and liabilities and their respective tax basis, and operating loss and tax credit carry forwards. &nbsp;Deferred tax assets and liabilities are measured using enacted tax rates expected to apply to taxable income in the years in which those temporary differences are expected to be recovered or settled. &nbsp;The effect on deferred tax assets and liabilities of a change in tax rates is recognized in income in the period that includes the enactment date. Valuation allowances are established when necessary to reduce deferred tax assets where it is more likely than not that the deferred tax asset will not be realized (see Note 12 of Notes to Consolidated Financial S
tatements).</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:13.333px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>In June 2006, the Financial Accounting Standards Board (the &#147;FASB&#148;) issued Interpretation No. 48, Accounting for Uncertainty in Income Taxes &#150; An Interpretation of FASB Statement No. 109 (&quot;Interpretation 48&quot;), which prescribes a recognition threshold and measurement attribute for the financial statement recognition and measurement of a tax position taken or expected to be taken in a tax return. Interpretation 48 also provides guidance on derecognition, classification, interest and penalties, accounting in interim periods, disclosure and transition. &nbsp;Interpretation 48 is effective for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2006. &nbsp;The adoption of Interpretation 48 on January 31, 2007 did not have a material effect on the Company&#146;s financial statements and the Company believes there are no significant tax positions that would require disclosure under Interpretation 48. 
&nbsp;The Internal Revenue Service is currently auditing our 2003 and 2004 consolidated income tax returns. &nbsp;It is anticipated that this examination will be completed within the next twelve months. &nbsp;Management believes that it has made adequate provision for all income tax uncertainties, such that the outcome of any unresolved issues or claims will not result in a material change to our financial position or results of operations.</P>
<P style="margin-top:13.333px; margin-bottom:0px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B><I>Stock-Based Compensation and Change in Accounting Principle</I></B></P>
<P style="margin-top:13.333px; margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>On January 1, 2006, the Company adopted the provisions of SFAS No. 123 (R), &quot;Share Based Payment&quot;, which requires compensation cost relating to share-based payment transactions to be recognized in the financial statements, based upon the fair value of the instruments issued. &nbsp;SFAS No. 123 (R) covers a wide range of share-based compensation arrangements including share options, restricted stock plans, performance-based awards, share appreciation rights and employee purchase plans. &nbsp;SFAS No. 123 (R) replaces SFAS No. 123. &nbsp;In March 2005, the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) issued Staff Accounting Bulletin No. 107 (SAB 107) regarding the SEC's interpretation of SFAS No. 123 (R) and the valuation of share-based payments for public companies. The company has applied the provisions of SAB 107 in its adoption of SFAS No. 123 (R) and accordingly recorded share-based payment expense i
n selling, general and administrative expenses. &nbsp;Since the Company previously adopted the provisions of SFAS No. 123, effective November 14, 2002, the adoption of SFAS No. 123 (R) did not have a material impact on the Company's Consolidated Financial Statements.</P>
<P style="margin-top:13.333px; margin-bottom:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
</DIV><DIV style="width:666.267px"><P style="line-height:13pt; margin:0px; font-family:Arial; font-size:11pt">45</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
</DIV><DIV style="width:586px"><P style="margin-top:13.333px; margin-bottom:0px; font-family:Arial; page-break-before:always" align=justify><B><I>Income Per Common Share</I></B></P>
<P style="margin-top:13.333px; margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Basic income per common share is computed using the weighted average number of common stock shares outstanding during the period. &nbsp;Diluted income per common share is computed using the weighted average number of common stock shares and common stock equivalent shares outstanding during the period. &nbsp;Common stock equivalents consist of stock options (using the &quot;treasury stock&quot; method). &nbsp;Common stock equivalent shares are excluded from the computation if the effect is anti-dilutive. &nbsp;As a result of the anti-dilutive effect, common stock equivalent shares have been excluded from the computation of diluted earnings per share for periods presented with a net loss. &nbsp;Included in the diluted earnings per share calculation for years 2007 and 2006, are 51,000 and 54,000 shares, respectively, from the assumed exercise of options using the treasury stock method. &nbsp;Net income does not 
change as a result of the assumed dilution of options.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B><I>Recent Accounting Pronouncements</I></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:51.333px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>In September 2006, the FASB issued SFAS No. 157, &#147;Fair Value Measurements&#148; (&#147;SFAS 157&#148;), which defines fair value, establishes a framework for measuring fair value and expands disclosures about fair value measurements. &nbsp;This Statement applies under other accounting pronouncements that require or permit fair value measurements. &nbsp;FASB Staff Position FIN 157-2, &quot;Effective Date of FASB Statement No. 157&quot;, amends SFAS 157 to defer its effective date to fiscal years beginning after November 15, 2008, and for interim periods within those fiscal years. &nbsp;The delayed effective date applies to all non-financial assets and non-financial liabilities except for items that are recognized or disclosed at fair value in the financial statements on a recurring basis (at least annually). &nbsp;The Company is in the process of analyzing the effects of adoption of SFAS 157 on the Company&#146;s consolidated fi
nancial statements.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:13.333px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>In February 2007, the FASB issued Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No. 159, &quot;The Fair Value Option for Financial Assets and Financial Liabilities - Including an Amendment of FASB Statement No. 115&quot; (&quot;SFAS 159&quot;). &nbsp;SFAS 159 would create a fair value option of accounting for qualifying financial assets and liabilities under which an irrevocable election could be made at inception to measure such assets and liabilities initially and subsequently at fair value, with all changes in fair value reported in earnings. &nbsp;SFAS 159 is effective as of the beginning of the first fiscal year beginning after November 15, 2007. &nbsp;The adoption of SFAS 159 is optional. &nbsp;The Company is in the process of analyzing the effects of adoption of SFAS 159 on the Company&#146;s consolidated financial statements.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:13.333px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>In November 2007, the FASB issued Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No 141 (revised 2007), &#147;Business Combinations&#148; (&#147;SFAS 141(R)&#148;) and Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No. 160, &#147;Noncontrolling Interests in Consolidated Financial Statements&#148;, an amendment of ARB No. 51 (&#147;SFAS 160&#148;). &nbsp;These standards aim to improve, simplify, and converge internationally the accounting for business combinations and the reporting of noncontrolling interests in consolidated financial statements. &nbsp;SFAS 141(R) will change how business acquisitions are accounted for and will impact financial statements both on the acquisition date and in subsequent periods. &nbsp;SFAS 160 will change the accounting and reporting for minority interests, which will be recharacterized as noncontrolling interests and classified as a component of equity. &nbsp;SFAS 141(R) and SFAS 160
 are effective for both public and private companies for fiscal years beginning on or after December 15, 2008. &nbsp;SFAS 141(R) will be applied prospectively. &nbsp;SFAS 160 requires retroactive adoption of the presentation and disclosure requirements for existing minority interests. &nbsp;All other requirements of SFAS 160 will be applied prospectively. &nbsp;Early adoption is prohibited for both standards. &nbsp;The Company is in the process of analyzing the effects of adoption of SFAS 141(R) and SFAS 160 on the Company&#146;s consolidated financial statements.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:13.333px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
</DIV><DIV style="width:666.267px"><P style="line-height:13pt; margin:0px; font-family:Arial; font-size:11pt">46</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>

<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The Company completed its annual impairment testing of goodwill and determined an impairment charge was not required as of December 31, 2007.</P>

<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>On October 5, 2007, the Company acquired certain assets, including the domain name www.healthinsurance.org, for $430,000 including closing costs of $55,000. &nbsp;The Company recorded $318,000 of goodwill and $112,000 of intangible assets representing the value of the <FONT style="color:#0000FF"><U>www.healthinsurance.org</U></FONT> internet domain name and related internet relationships which will be amortized over 15 years. &nbsp;These assets were acquired by HealthInsurance.org, LLC, an indirect, 51%-owned subsidiary of the Company (&#147;HIO&#148;). &nbsp;This acquisition gives the Company access to a well-established internet domain that generates hundreds of daily leads of business from individuals and small employers seeking affordable health insurance solutions. &nbsp;Under certain circumstances set forth in the operating agreement of HIO, the Company has the right and/or obligation to purchase some or all of the minority intere
st in HIO.</P>

</TABLE>
<P style="margin-top:13.333px; margin-bottom:0px; padding-right:-0.667px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Government-sponsored enterprise mortgage-backed securities consist of Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation and Federal National Mortgage Association securities.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:6.667px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:6.667px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The amortized cost and fair value of fixed maturities at December 31, 2007 by contractual maturity are shown below. &nbsp;Expected maturities will differ from contractual maturities because borrowers may have the right to call or prepay obligations with or without call or prepayment penalties. &nbsp;The average life of mortgage backed securities is affected by prepayments on the underlying loans and, therefore, is materially shorter than the original stated maturity.</P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:6.667px" align=justify><BR></P>

<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Substantially all of the unrealized losses at December 31, 2007 and 2006 relate to investment grade securities and are attributable to changes in market interest rates and general disruptions in the credit market subsequent to purchase. &nbsp;The Company reviews its investments regularly and monitors its investments for impairments. &nbsp;At December 31, 2007, the Company had $1.6 million invested in whole loan CMOs backed by Alt-A mortgages, all of which were rated AAA. &nbsp;Of this amount, 79.0% were in CMOs that originated in 2005 or earlier and 21.0% were in CMOs that originated in 2006. &nbsp;The decline in market value for the equity securities was primarily due to wider spreads for preferred stocks issued by financial institutions following the disruption in credit markets in late 2007.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>A total of 24 securities were in a continuous unrealized loss position for less than 12 months and 51 securities for 12 months or longer as of December 2007. &nbsp;A total of 31 securities were in a continuous unrealized loss position for less than 12 months and 54 securities for 12 months or longer as of December 31, 2006. &nbsp;For fixed maturities, there are no securities past due or securities for which the Company currently believes it is not probable that it will collect all amounts due according to the contractual terms of the investment. Based on management's review of the portfolio, which considered the various factors described in Note 2 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements, including management&#146;s expectations for recovery in fair value and the Company's intent and ability to hold securities for a period of time sufficient to allow for such </P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
</DIV><DIV style="width:666.267px"><P style="line-height:13pt; margin:0px; font-family:Arial; font-size:11pt">50</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
</DIV><DIV style="width:586px"><P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial; page-break-before:always" align=justify>recovery in fair value, the Company did not consider these investments to be other-than-temporarily impaired at December 31, 2007 and 2006.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The Company had derivative instruments representing the value of the contingent payment due to EDH as of December 31, 2007 and 2006 (see Note 18 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements).</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Gross gains of $112,000 and gross losses of $115,000 were realized on sales of available-for-sale securities for the year ended December 31, 2007.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Gross gains of $115,000 and gross losses of $336,000 were realized on sales of available-for-sale securities for the year ended December 31, 2006.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The Company maintains a securities trading account in addition to its securities classified as available-for-sale. &nbsp;The Company realized net gains from trading securities of $319,000 in 2007 and $392,000 in 2006. &nbsp;The Company had $4,500,000 and $4,000,000 million, on average, in trading securities during 2007 and 2006, respectively. &nbsp;All such trading securities were liquidated at December 31, 2007 and 2006.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>

<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>6. &nbsp;Other Long-Term Investments</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:13.333px; margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>At December 31, 2007 and December 31, 2006, the Company had an equity investment in Majestic with a carrying value of $918,000 and $1,009,000, respectively. &nbsp;For years 2007 and 2006, the Company recorded $(28,000) and $102,000, respectively, for its share of income (loss) </P>
<P style="margin-top:13.333px; margin-bottom:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
</DIV><DIV style="width:666.267px"><P style="line-height:13pt; margin:0px; font-family:Arial; font-size:11pt">51</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
</DIV><DIV style="width:586px"><P style="margin-top:13.333px; margin-bottom:0px; font-family:Arial; page-break-before:always" align=justify>from its investment in Majestic in Net Investment Income in the Consolidated Statements of Operations.</P>

<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial"><B>8. &nbsp;Discontinued Operations</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Until April 2002, the Company (then known as SoftNet Systems, Inc.) was an Internet service provider. &nbsp;Due to difficult and deteriorating conditions in that market, the Company discontinued this business. &nbsp;In December 2000, the Company's board of directors approved a plan to discontinue the operations of its subsidiary, ISP Channel, Inc., which had provided cable-based Internet access and related services, and the operations of another subsidiary, Aerzone Corporation, which provided Internet and related services at airports. &nbsp;In April 2002, the Company, ceased operations of its remaining operating subsidiary, Intelligent Communications, Inc., following the disposition of its key assets. &nbsp;The operating results of discontinued operations have been segregated from continuing operations and are reported as a gain or loss from discontinued operations on the consolidated statements of operations. &nbsp;Although it is diffi
cult to predict the final results, the gain or loss on disposition from discontinued operations includes management's estimates of costs to wind down the business and costs to settle its outstanding liabilities. &nbsp;The actual results could differ from these estimates. &nbsp;The net liabilities associated with discontinued operations are reflected in net liabilities associated with discontinued operations in the accompanying consolidated balance sheets.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Discontinued Operations of Intelligent Communications, Inc.</I></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Following the sale of its operating business and certain assets on March 29, 2002, the Company's board of directors unanimously agreed to cease the operations of Intellicom on April 3, 2002. &nbsp;Principally due to the Company's guaranty of Intellicom's lease for its facility in Livermore, California, the Company has reserves for discontinued operations of Intellicom of $399,000 for this liability at December 31, 2007, and $555,000 at December 31, 2006. &nbsp;In October of 2006, the Company entered into an agreement with a third party to sublease the property in Livermore, California for the remaining life of the lease. &nbsp;The income associated with the sublease was previously estimated in the reserve balance. &nbsp;Loss from disposition of discontinued operations results from re-estimation of certain expected expenses.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>

<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>

<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>9. &nbsp;Commitments and Contingencies</B></P>
<P style="margin-top:13.333px; margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Fixed maturities with a carrying value of $4,775,000 are on deposit with various state insurance departments at December 31, 2007.</P>
<P style="margin-top:13.333px; margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The Company has operating leases for office space and certain other office equipment. &nbsp;These operating leases provide for minimum rents and generally include options to renew for additional periods.</P>
<P style="margin-top:13.333px; margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Future minimum lease payments under non-cancelable operating leases as of December 31, 2007, are as follows (in thousands):</P>
