<P style="margin-top:13.333px; margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The Company's net rent expense for years 2007 and 2006 were $357,000 and $649,000, respectively.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The Company has additional obligations in regard to its agreement with EDH as further described in Note 18 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Under certain circumstances set forth in the Limited Liability Company Agreements of Marlton and Majestic, the Company has the right and/or obligation to purchase some or all of the minority interests in Marlton and Majestic.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Independence American maintains a $5,000,000 credit facility with a financial institution to support the issuance of standby letters of credit in connection with Independence American&#146;s ordinary course of business. &nbsp;This credit facility has never been drawn upon and there are no </P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
</DIV><DIV style="width:666.267px"><P style="line-height:13pt; margin:0px; font-family:Arial; font-size:11pt">53</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
</DIV><DIV style="width:586px"><P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial; page-break-before:always" align=justify>outstanding standby letters of credit under the facility. &nbsp;The facility terminates on December 28, 2009, although, to the extent no standby letters of credit are outstanding, it may be reduced or cancelled by Independence American at any time.</P>
<P style="margin-top:13.333px; margin-bottom:0px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B><I>Legal Proceedings</I></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The Company is involved in legal proceedings and claims that arise in the ordinary course of its businesses. &nbsp;The Company has established reserves that it believes are sufficient given information presently available relating to its outstanding legal proceedings and claims. &nbsp;The Company does not anticipate that the result of any pending legal proceeding or claim will have a material adverse effect on its financial condition or cash flows, although there could be such an effect on its results of operations for any particular period.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>10. &nbsp;Stock Options </B></P>
<P style="margin-top:13.333px; margin-bottom:0px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B><I>1998 Stock Incentive Plan (&quot;1998 Plan&quot;)</I></B></P>
<P style="margin-top:13.333px; margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Effective October 1, 1998, the Company implemented the 1998 Plan, which the Company's stockholders approved on April 13, 1999. &nbsp;The 1998 Plan provides for the grants of non-statutory and incentive stock options, stock appreciation rights, restricted stock awards, performance shares, and other awards to officers, employee and other individuals. &nbsp;Under the terms of the 1998 Plan, stock options have a maximum term of ten years from the date of grant, and have various vesting criteria depending on the grant with most grants vesting 25% on the first year anniversary date of the grant and ratably over the next 36 months. &nbsp;In addition, the number of common stock shares reserved for issuance under the 1998 Plan will automatically increase on the first trading day of each calendar year, beginning in calendar year 2000, by an amount equal to seven percent of the total number of common stock shares outsta
nding on the last trading day of the preceding calendar year, but in no event will any such annual increase exceed 1,333,333 shares, subject to adjustment for subsequent stock splits, stock dividends and similar transactions. &nbsp;At December 31, 2007, a total of 6,558,919 stock shares are reserved for issuance under the 1998 Plan. &nbsp;At December 31, 2007, stock options for 443,499 common stock shares were outstanding, stock options for 381,971 common stock shares were vested, and 5,968,611 common stock shares remained available for future stock options grants and other awards.</P>
<P style="margin-top:13.333px; margin-bottom:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
</DIV><DIV style="width:666.267px"><P style="line-height:13pt; margin:0px; font-family:Arial; font-size:11pt">54</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>

<TR><TD valign=top width=178.6><P>&nbsp;</P></TD><TD valign=bottom width=73><P>&nbsp;</P></TD><TD valign=bottom width=15.733><P>&nbsp;</P></TD><TD valign=bottom width=21.4><P>&nbsp;</P></TD><TD valign=bottom width=54.933><P>&nbsp;</P></TD><TD valign=top width=15.733><P>&nbsp;</P></TD><TD valign=top width=15.733><P>&nbsp;</P></TD></TR>
</TABLE>
<P style="margin-top:13.333px; margin-bottom:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial"><B><I>Stock-Based Compensation</I></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>On January 1, 2006, the Company adopted the provisions of SFAS No. 123 (R), &quot;Share Based Payment&quot;, which requires compensation cost relating to share-based payment transactions to be recognized in the financial statements, based upon the fair value of the instruments issued. &nbsp;SFAS No. 123 (R) covers a wide range of share-based compensation arrangements including share options, restricted stock plans, performance-based awards, share appreciation rights and employee purchase plans. &nbsp;SFAS No. 123 (R) replaces SFAS No. 123, which established as preferable a fair value based method of accounting for share-based compensation with employees, but permitted the option of continuing to apply the guidance of APB Opinion No. 25, as long as the notes to the financial statements disclosed the effects of the preferable fair value method. &nbsp;In March 2005, the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) issued Staff Accounting Bulle
tin No. 107 (SAB 107) regarding the SEC's interpretation of SFAS No. 123 (R) and the valuation of share-based payments for public companies. The Company has applied the provisions of SAB 107 in its adoption of SFAS No. 123 (R) and accordingly recorded share-based payment expense in Selling, General and Administrative expenses in the Consolidated Statements of Operations. &nbsp;Since the Company previously adopted the provisions of SFAS No. 123, effective November 14, 2002, the adoption of SFAS No. 123 (R) did not have a material impact on the Company's Consolidated Financial Statements.</P>
<P style="margin-top:13.333px; margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Total share-based compensation expense was $231,000 and $235,000 for the twelve months ended December 31, 2007 and 2006, respectively. &nbsp;Related tax benefits of $81,000 and $82,000 for the twelve months ended December 31, 2007 and 2006, respectively. &nbsp;As of December 31, 2007, there was approximately $226,000 of total unrecognized compensation expense related to non-vested options which will be recognized over the remaining requisite service periods.</P>
<P style="margin-top:13.333px; margin-bottom:0px" align=justify><BR>

</DIV><DIV style="width:666.267px"><P style="line-height:13pt; margin:0px; font-family:Arial; font-size:11pt">55</P>

<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>11. &nbsp;Related Party Transactions</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Independence American is primarily a reinsurer, and currently derives most of its business from pro rata quota share reinsurance treaties with Standard Security Life and Madison National Life, which are wholly owned subsidiaries of IHC. &nbsp;These treaties were entered into in 2002 and terminate on December 31, 2014, unless terminated sooner by Independence American. &nbsp;Standard Security Life and Madison National Life must cede at least 15% of their medical stop-loss business to Independence American under these treaties. &nbsp;Additionally, Standard Security Life, Madison National Life and Independence American have received regulatory approval to cede up to 30% to Independence American under most of IHC&#146;s medical stop-loss programs. For the twelve months ended December 31, 2007 and 2006, Standard Security Life and Madison National Life ceded an average of 22.7% and 22.2%, respectively, of their medical stop-loss business to I
ndependence American. Commencing in July 2004, Independence American began reinsuring 20% of Standard Security Life&#146;s short-term statutory disability benefit product (&#147;DBL&#148;) business. &nbsp;In 2005, Standard Security Life and Madison National Life began ceding 10% of the majority of its fully insured health business to Independence American.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-right:-15.333px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Independence American assumes these premiums from Standard Security Life and Madison National Life, and records related insurance income, expenses, assets and liabilities. &nbsp;Independence American pays administrative fees and commissions to subsidiaries of IHC in connection with fully insured health business written by Independence American. &nbsp;Additionally, our MGUs market, underwrite and provide administrative services (including premium collection, medical management and claims adjudication) for a substantial portion of the medical stop-loss business written by the insurance subsidiaries of IHC and records related income, assets and liabilities in connection with that business. &nbsp;Such related party information is disclosed on the Consolidated Balance Sheets and Consolidated Statements of Operations. &nbsp;The Company also contracts for several types of insurance coverage (e.g. directors and officers
 and professional liability coverage) jointly with IHC. &nbsp;The cost of </P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
</DIV><DIV style="width:666.267px"><P style="line-height:13pt; margin:0px; font-family:Arial; font-size:11pt">56</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
</DIV><DIV style="width:586px"><P style="margin:0px; padding-right:-15.333px; font-family:Arial; page-break-before:always" align=justify>this coverage is split proportionally between the Company and IHC according to the type of risk and AMIC&#146;s portion is recorded in Selling, General and Administrative Expenses.</P>
<P style="margin-top:13.333px; margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>IHC provides the Company with pro rata quota share reinsurance on business written by Independence American. &nbsp;Commencing in January 2004, Independence American began ceding 30% of its provider excess insurance to Madison National Life. &nbsp;In January 2005, Independence American increased the amount ceded to Madison National Life to 55%. This treaty was entered into on January 1, 2004 and will remain in force for an indefinite period, unless terminated by either party as of any December 31. &nbsp;The Company is not aware of any regulatory or other restrictions on the ability of IHC to fund its obligations under agreements in which IHC reinsures such provider excess business. &nbsp;Any such restrictions would at this point have a minimal impact on the Company. &nbsp;In addition, in 2007, Independence American ceded 50% of its STM and major medical for individuals and families business to unrelated reinsu
rers.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>AMIC and its subsidiaries incurred expense of $776,000 and $622,000 for the twelve months ended December 31, 2007 and 2006, respectively, from its service agreements with IHC and its subsidiaries. &nbsp;These payments reimburse IHC and its subsidiaries, at agreed upon rates including an overhead factor, for management services provided to AMIC and its subsidiaries, including accounting, legal, compliance, underwriting, and claims.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-right:-15.333px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>12. &nbsp;Income Taxes</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The Company and its subsidiaries file a consolidated Federal income tax return on a September 30 fiscal tax year. &nbsp;The provision (benefit) for income taxes for the periods ended December 31, 2007 and 2006 are as follows:</P>

<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The Federal income tax provision (benefit) for the periods ending December 31, 2007 and 2006 include income tax provisions of $537,000 and $792,000, respectively, for the utilization of the Company's Federal net operating loss carryforwards (NOLs). The Company recorded deferred tax benefits on discontinued operations of $0 and $29,000 for the periods ending December 31, 2007 and 2006, which were included in Gain (loss) on Disposition of Discontinued Operations, net of tax, in the Statement of Operations.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>

<TR><TD valign=top width=261.533 colspan=2><P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Net deferred tax asset</P>

<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>During the year ended December 31, 2007, the Company decreased its valuation allowance by $3,000 representing a decrease of deferred tax on unrealized losses allocated to </P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
</DIV><DIV style="width:666.267px"><P style="line-height:13pt; margin:0px; font-family:Arial; font-size:11pt">58</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
</DIV><DIV style="width:586px"><P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial; page-break-before:always" align=justify>equity. &nbsp;During the year ended December 31, 2006, the Company increased its valuation allowance by $44,000, representing an increase of deferred tax on unrealized losses allocated to equity.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>In assessing the realizability of deferred tax assets, management considers whether it is more likely than not that some portion or all of the deferred tax assets will not be realized. The ultimate realization of deferred tax assets is dependent upon the generation of future taxable income during the period in which those temporary differences become deductible. Management considers the scheduled reversal of deferred tax liabilities, projected future taxable income, and tax planning strategies in making this assessment. Management believes that it is more likely than not that the Company will realize the benefits of these net deferred tax assets recorded at December 31, 2007.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>At December 31, 2007, the Company had Federal net operating loss carryforwards of approximately $275,104,000 which expire as follows (in thousands).</P>

<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>At December 31, 2007, the Company also had net operating loss carryforwards of approximately $25,814,000 for state income tax purposes, primarily in the State of California. &nbsp;Management believes that it is more likely than not that the state tax benefit of these net operating loss carryforwards will not be realized.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The Internal Revenue Service (&quot;IRS&quot;) is currently auditing the Company&#146;s 2003 and 2004 consolidated income tax returns. &nbsp;The IRS has not audited any of AMIC's tax returns for any of the years during the carryforward period, including those returns for the years in which the losses giving rise to the NOL carryforward were reported. &nbsp;Management believes that it has made adequate provision for all income tax uncertainties, such that the outcome of any unresolved issues or claims will not result in a material change to our financial position or results of operations.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>AMIC's ability to utilize its Federal Net Operating Loss Carrryforwards (&quot;NOLs&quot;) would be substantially reduced if AMIC were to undergo an &quot;ownership change&quot; within the meaning of Section 382(g)(1) of the Internal Revenue Code. AMIC will be treated as having had an &quot;ownership change&quot; if there is more than a 50% increase in stock ownership during a three year '&quot;testing period&quot; by &quot;5% stockholders.&quot; &nbsp;In order to reduce the risk of an ownership change, in November 2002, AMIC's stockholders approved an amendment to its Certificate of Incorporation restricting transfers of shares of its common stock that could result in the imposition of limitations on the use, for federal, state and city income tax purposes, of AMIC's carryforwards of net operating losses and certain federal income tax credits. &nbsp;The Certificate of Incorporation generally restricts any person from attempting to sell
, transfer or dispose, or purchase or acquire any AMIC stock, if such transfer would affect the percentage of AMIC stock owned by a 5% stockholder. &nbsp;Any person attempting such a transfer will be required, prior to the date of any proposed transfer, to request in writing that the board of directors review the proposed transfer and authorize or not authorize such proposed transfer. &nbsp;Any transfer attempted to be made in violation of the stock transfer restrictions will be null and void. &nbsp;In the event of an attempted or purported transfer involving a sale or disposition of </P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
</DIV><DIV style="width:666.267px"><P style="line-height:13pt; margin:0px; font-family:Arial; font-size:11pt">59</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
</DIV><DIV style="width:586px"><P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial; page-break-before:always" align=justify>capital stock in violation of stock transfer restrictions, the transferor shall remain the owner of such shares. &nbsp;Notwithstanding such transfer restrictions, there could be circumstances under which an issuance by AMIC of a significant number of new shares of Common Stock or other new class of equity security having certain characteristics (for example, the right to vote or convert into Common Stock) might result in an ownership change under the Code.</P>
<P style="margin-top:13.333px; margin-bottom:0px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>13. &nbsp;Insurance Reserves</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The Company maintains loss reserves to cover its estimated liability for unpaid losses and loss adjustment expenses, including legal and other fees and a portion of the Company's general expenses, for reported and unreported claims incurred as of the end of each accounting period. These loss reserves are based on actuarial assumptions and are maintained at levels that are in accordance with GAAP. Many factors could affect these reserves, including economic and social conditions, inflation, healthcare costs, changes in doctrines of legal liability and damage awards in litigation. Therefore, the Company's reserves are necessarily based on estimates, assumptions and analysis of historical experience. The Company's results depend upon the variation between actual claims experience and the assumptions used in determining reserves and pricing products. Reserve assumptions and estimates require significant judgment and, therefore, are inherent
ly uncertain. The Company cannot determine with precision the ultimate amounts that will be paid for actual claims or the timing of those payments.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Reserves are based on approved actuarial methods, but necessarily include assumptions about expenses, mortality, morbidity, lapse rates and future yield on related investments.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>All of the Company's short-duration contracts are generated from our accident and health business, and are accounted for based on actuarial estimates of the amount of loss inherent in that period's claims, including losses incurred for which claims have not been reported. Short-duration contract loss estimates rely on actuarial observations of ultimate loss experience for similar historical events.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>

<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The preceding schedule reflects (i) the due and unpaid, (ii) claims in the course of settlement, (iii) estimated incurred but not reported reserves and (iv) the present value of amounts not yet due on claims. The incurred and paid data above reflects all activity for the year. &nbsp;The </P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
</DIV><DIV style="width:666.267px"><P style="line-height:13pt; margin:0px; font-family:Arial; font-size:11pt">60</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
</DIV><DIV style="width:586px"><P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial; page-break-before:always" align=justify>amount incurred in 2007 of $2,964,000 is a result of the re-estimation of unpaid losses on medical stop-loss reserves of $2,778,000 and of fully insured health reserves of $438,000, slightly offset by a redundancy of $252,000 of DBL reserves. &nbsp;The amount incurred in 2006 for prior years of $1,969,000 is primarily a result of re-estimation of unpaid losses on medical stop-loss reserves. &nbsp;These increases are generally the result of on-going analysis of recent loss development trends.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Medical stop-loss business is excess coverage with a short duration. &nbsp;Predicting ultimate claims and estimating reserves in medical stop-loss is especially complicated due to the &#147;excess of loss&#148; nature of these products with very high deductibles applying to specific claims on any individual claimant and in the aggregate for a given group. &nbsp;Fluctuations in results for specific coverage are primarily due to the severity and frequency of individual claims. &nbsp;Due to the short-term nature of medical stop-loss, redundancies and deficiencies will typically emerge during the following year rather than over a number of years. &nbsp;In the third quarter of 2007, the Company identified a material increase in claims and reserves with respect to business written in 2006. &nbsp;Such adverse development was primarily driven by the frequency of claims relative to the business written in that year proving significantly higher t
han what would have been predicted by prior loss development patterns. &nbsp;This increased frequency of medical stop-loss claims was due, in part, to increased severity of primary claims.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>14. &nbsp;Reinsurance</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Independence American reinsures a portion of its small-group major medical, major medical for individuals and families, and provider excess loss business in order to limit the assumption of disproportionate risks. &nbsp;Amounts not retained are ceded to other companies on an automatic basis. &nbsp;Independence American is contingently liable with respect to reinsurance in the unlikely event that the assuming reinsurers are unable to meet their obligations. &nbsp;The ceding of reinsurance does not discharge the primary liability of the original insurer to the insured. &nbsp;At December 31, 2007, Independence American ceded to highly rated reinsurers.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The effect of reinsurance on insurance benefits and premiums earned is as follows (in thousands):</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>

<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial"><B>15. &nbsp;Dividend Restrictions on Insurance Subsidiary</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Dividends from Independence American to its parent, a subsidiary of AMIC, are subject to the prior notification to the Delaware Insurance Commissioner, if such dividends, together with the fair market<B> </B>value of other dividends or distributions made within the preceding twelve months, exceed the greater of (i) 10% of surplus as regards policyholders as of the preceding December 31 or (ii) net income, not including realized capital gains, for the twelve-month period ending the 31<SUP>st</SUP> day of December next preceding. &nbsp;Such dividends may be paid so long as they have not been </P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
</DIV><DIV style="width:666.267px"><P style="line-height:13pt; margin:0px; font-family:Arial; font-size:11pt">61</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
</DIV><DIV style="width:586px"><P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial; page-break-before:always" align=justify>disapproved by the Delaware Insurance Commissioner within 30 days of its receipt of notice thereof. &nbsp;Independence American did not pay any dividends in 2007 and 2006.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Independence American&#146;s statutory surplus was $41,353,000 as of December 31, 2007 and $40,778,000 as of December 31, 2006. &nbsp;Independence American&#146;s statutory net income was $1,325,000 for 2007 and $1,897,000 for 2006.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>16. &nbsp;Segment Information</B></P>

Corporate assets are composed principally of cash equivalents, resale agreements, and partnership interests. &nbsp;Information by business segment for the years ended December 31, 2007 and 2006 is presented below (in thousands):</P>

<TABLE style="font-size:10pt" cellspacing=0><TR height=0 style="font-size:0; display:none"><TD width=21.2></TD><TD width=262.333></TD><TD width=15.733></TD><TD width=27.133></TD><TD width=91.067></TD><TD width=25.533></TD><TD width=83.867></TD></TR>
</TABLE>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>17. &nbsp;Other Comprehensive Income</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The components of total comprehensive income, net of tax, include net income and certain amounts reported directly in equity, such as the after-tax unrealized gains and losses on investment securities available-for-sale. &nbsp;The components of other comprehensive income for years 2007 and 2006 are as follows:</P>
<TABLE style="font-size:10pt" cellspacing=0><TR height=0 style="font-size:0; display:none"><TD width=15.733></TD><TD width=362.8></TD><TD width=17.333></TD><TD width=66></TD><TD width=4.667></TD><TD width=17.333></TD><TD width=22></TD><TD width=66></TD></TR>
<TR><TD valign=top width=378.533 colspan=2><P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
</TD><TD valign=top width=17.333><P>&nbsp;</P></TD><TD style="border-bottom:1px solid #000000" valign=top width=176 colspan=5><P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial" align=center><B>Net of tax</B></P>

</TABLE>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial"><B>18. &nbsp;Marketing Agreements</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>In February 2006, Independence American entered into an agreement with Employers Direct Health (&#147;EDH&#148;). &nbsp;Under this agreement, EDH began writing employer medical stop-loss for Independence American in 2006, and moved the majority of its existing block of employer-sponsored group major medical and medical stop-loss to Independence American during 2007. &nbsp;The employer-sponsored group major medical product is part of the Company&#146;s fully insured health line of business. &nbsp;In 2006, Independence American paid EDH $2,500,000, which EDH simultaneously paid to Independence Holding Company (&#147;IHC&#148;) in consideration of IHC issuing 125,000 shares of IHC common stock (&#147;IHC Stock&#148;) to EDH. &nbsp;The IHC stock will be released to EDH upon aggregate annualized premiums generated by EDH reaching $30 million, less such number of shares necessary to satisfy EDH&#146;s obligation under the agreement to provide
 certain collateral to Independence American. &nbsp;As of December 31, 2007, Independence American received $26,895,000 of earned premiums under this agreement.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The EDH Agreement terminates on December 31, 2011; provided, it will automatically be extended to December 31, 2016, subject to satisfaction of certain conditions as to premium volume and profitability. Assuming these conditions are satisfied, EDH would be entitled to up to an additional $2,500,000 depending on the value of the IHC Stock as of December 31, 2011. &nbsp;The Company recorded a derivative liability and an intangible asset on its Consolidated Balance Sheet in the amount of $743,000 to account for the fair value of such contingent payment at closing. &nbsp;The value of the derivative liability is evaluated each quarter and the corresponding change in fair value is reflected in net realized investment gains in the Consolidated Statements of Operations. &nbsp;As of December 31, 2007, the value of the derivative liability is $1,248,000. &nbsp;The value of the derivative increased $409,000 for the twelve months ended December 31,
 2007. &nbsp;If the EDH Agreement is extended to December 31, 2016, subject to satisfaction of certain further conditions as to premium volume and profitability, EDH would be entitled to up to an additional $5,000,000 depending on the value of the IHC Stock as of December 31, 2016. &nbsp;In addition, EDH could be entitled to a $1,000,000 bonus on December 31, 2013 subject to satisfaction of certain conditions as to premium volume and profitability.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The Company has classified the $2,500,000 payment and $743,000 original value of the derivative as an intangible asset that will be amortized over the five year contract period. &nbsp;Such amortization started January 1, 2007 to coincide with the transfer of business on January 1, 2007.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
</DIV><DIV style="width:666.267px"><P style="line-height:13pt; margin:0px; font-family:Arial; font-size:11pt">63</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
</DIV><DIV style="width:586px"><P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial; page-break-before:always" align=justify>As part of the agreement, an affiliate of EDH and Independence American entered into a profit/loss sharing arrangement, whereby Independence American will pay to, or receive from, such affiliate 35% of the underwriting profit or loss of the business written for Independence American.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>In addition, the Company began marketing health plans to individuals and families utilizing Independence American as the carrier during the third quarter of 2007. &nbsp;Independence American retains 50% of the risk on this business. &nbsp;The program is administered by Insurers Administrative Corporation, a wholly owned subsidiary of IHC.</P>
<P style="margin-top:13.333px; margin-bottom:-16px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B>Item 9.</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><B><I>Changes in and Disagreements with Accountants on Accounting and Financial Disclosure</I></B></P>
<P style="margin-top:13.333px; margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>None</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial"><B>Item 9A (T). <I>Controls and Procedures</I></B></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Evaluation of Disclosure Controls and Procedures</I></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>A review and evaluation was performed by management under the supervision and with the participation of the Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer of the effectiveness of the Company's disclosure controls and procedures, as required by Rule 13a-15(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 as of December 31, 2007. &nbsp;Based upon that most recent evaluation, which was completed as of the end of the period covered by this Form 10-K, the Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer concluded that the Company's disclosure controls and procedures were effective at December 31, 2007 to ensure that information required to be disclosed in reports that the Company files under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is recorded, processed, summarized and timely reported as provided in the Securities and Exchange Commission (&quot;SEC&quot;) rules and forms. &nbsp;As a result of this evaluation, there were no significant deficienc
ies in the Company's internal control over financial reporting during the twelve months ended December 31, 2007 that have materially affected or are reasonably likely to materially affect the Company's internal control over financial reporting.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Management Report on Internal Control Over Financial Reporting</I></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Management of the Company is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting as defined in Rules 13a-15(b) and 15d-15(f) under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended, as a process designed by, or under the supervision of the Company's principal executive and principal financial officers and effected by the Company's board, management and other personnel to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States (&quot;GAAP, US&quot;) and includes those policies and procedures that:</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>- pertain to the maintenance of records that in reasonable detail accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of a company;</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>- provide reasonable assurance that the transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with GAAP, US and that receipts and expenditures of a company are being made only in accordance with authorization of management and directors of a company; and</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>- provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use or disposition of a company's assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR>
<BR></P>
</DIV><DIV style="width:666.267px"><P style="line-height:13pt; margin:0px; font-family:Arial; font-size:11pt">64</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
</DIV><DIV style="width:586px"><P style="margin:0px; page-break-before:always" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Because of the inherent limitations of internal control over financial reporting, including the possibility of human error and the circumvention or overriding of controls, material misstatements may not be prevented or detected on a timely basis. Projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risks that controls may become inadequate because of changes and conditions or that the degree of compliance with policies or procedures may deteriorate. &nbsp;Accordingly, even internal controls determined to be effective can provide only reasonable assurance that information required to be disclosed in and reports filed under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is recorded, processed, summarized and represented within the time periods required.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>Management's report was not subject to attestation by the Company's registered public accounting firm pursuant to temporary rules of the SEC that permit the Company to provide only management's report in this annual report. &nbsp;As a result, this annual report does not include an attestation report of the Company's registered public accounting firm regarding internal control over financial reporting.</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial" align=justify><I>Changes in Internal Control Over Financial Reporting</I></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:48px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>There has been no change in the Company's internal control over financial reporting during the year ended December 31, 2007, that has materially affected, or is reasonably likely to materially affect, the Registrant's internal control over financial reporting.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>

<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:11pt; margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-14.667px; padding-left:120px; text-indent:-48px; font-family:Arial; font-size:9pt">(1)</P>
<P style="line-height:11pt; margin:0px; padding-left:120px; font-family:Arial; font-size:9pt">Net investment income is allocated between product lines based on the mean reserve method.</P>
<P style="line-height:11pt; margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-14.667px; padding-left:120px; text-indent:-48px; font-family:Arial; font-size:9pt">(2)</P>
<P style="line-height:11pt; margin:0px; padding-left:120px; font-family:Arial; font-size:9pt">Where possible, direct operating expenses are specifically identified and charged to product lines. Indirect expenses are allocated based on time studies; however, other acceptable methods of allocation might produce different results.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR>

<META NAME="date" CONTENT="03/11/2008">
</HEAD>
<BODY style="line-height:12pt; font-family:Times New Roman; font-size:10pt; color:#000000">
<DIV style="width:672px"><P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial" align=right><B>Exhibit 23.1 </B></P>
<P style="line-height:13pt; margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:15.867px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial" align=center><U>Consent of Independent Registered Public Accounting Firm</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial">The Board of Directors<BR>
American Independence Corp.:</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="line-height:13pt; margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:14.467px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>We consent to the incorporation by reference in the Registration Statements (No.&#146;s 333-78177. 333-80197, 333-84625, 333-33140 and 333-32962) on Forms S-8 of American Independence Corp. (formerly SoftNet Systems, Inc.) of our report dated March 17, 2008, with respect to the consolidated balance sheets of American Independence Corp. and subsidiaries as of December 31, 2007 and 2006 and the related consolidated statements of operations, stockholders' equity and cash flows for years then ended, and all related financial statement schedules, which report appears in the December 31, 2007, annual report on Form 10-K of American Independence Corp.</P>
<P style="line-height:13pt; margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:14.467px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>/s/ KPMG LLP</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial">New York, New York<BR>
March 17, 2008</P>

<!doctype html public "-//IETF//DTD HTML//EN">
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>To Our Shareholders</TITLE>
<META NAME="author" CONTENT="IHC">
<META NAME="date" CONTENT="03/11/2008">
</HEAD>
<BODY style="line-height:12pt; font-family:Times New Roman; font-size:10pt; color:#000000">
<DIV style="width:672px"><P style="margin:0px; padding-left:576px; font-family:Arial"><B>Exhibit 31.1 </B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=right><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial" align=center><B>CERTIFICATION PURSUANT TO RULE 13A-14(a) OR 15D-14(a) OF THE SECURITIES </B></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial" align=center><B>EXCHANGE ACT OF 1934, AS ADOPTED PURSUANT TO SECTION 302 OF THE </B></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial" align=center><B>SARBANES-OXLEY ACT OF 2002 </B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial">I, Roy T.K. Thung, certify that: </P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:32.667px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>1. I have reviewed this annual report on Form 10-K of American Independence Corp; </P>
<P style="line-height:9.5pt; margin:0px; font-family:Arial; font-size:7.5pt" align=justify>&nbsp;&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:32.667px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>2. Based on my knowledge, this report does not contain any untrue statement of a material fact or omit to state a material fact necessary to make the statements made, in light of the circumstances under which such statements were made, not misleading with respect to the period covered by this report; </P>
<P style="line-height:9.5pt; margin:0px; font-family:Arial; font-size:7.5pt" align=justify>&nbsp;&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:32.667px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>3. Based on my knowledge, the financial statements, and other financial information included in this report, fairly present in all material respects the financial condition, results of operations and cash flows of the registrant as of, and for, the periods presented in this report; </P>
<P style="line-height:9.5pt; margin:0px; font-family:Arial; font-size:7.5pt" align=justify>&nbsp;&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:32.667px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>4. The registrant's other certifying officer and I are responsible for establishing and maintaining disclosure controls and procedures (as defined in Exchange Act Rules 13a-15(e) and 15d-15(e)) and internal control over financial reporting (as defined in Exchange Act Rules 13a-15(f) and 15d-15(f)) for the registrant and have: </P>
<P style="line-height:9.5pt; margin:0px; font-family:Arial; font-size:7.5pt" align=justify>&nbsp;&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:32.6px; text-indent:32.667px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>(a) Designed such disclosure controls and procedures, or caused such disclosure controls and procedures to be designed under our supervision, to ensure that material information relating to the registrant, including its consolidated subsidiaries, is made known to us by others within those entities, particularly during the period in which this report is being prepared; </P>
<P style="line-height:9.5pt; margin:0px; font-family:Arial; font-size:7.5pt" align=justify>&nbsp;&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:32.6px; text-indent:32.667px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>(b) Designed such internal control over financial reporting, or caused such internal control over financial reporting to be designed under our supervision, to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles; </P>
<P style="line-height:9.5pt; margin:0px; font-family:Arial; font-size:7.5pt" align=justify>&nbsp;&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:32.6px; text-indent:32.667px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>(c) Evaluated the effectiveness of the registrant's disclosure controls and procedures and presented in this report our conclusions about the effectiveness of the disclosure controls and procedures, as of the end of the period covered by this report based on such evaluation; and </P>
<P style="line-height:9.5pt; margin:0px; font-family:Arial; font-size:7.5pt" align=justify>&nbsp;&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:32.6px; text-indent:32.667px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>(d) Disclosed in this report any change in the registrant's internal control over financial reporting that occurred during the registrant's most recent fiscal quarter (the registrant's fourth fiscal quarter in the case of an annual report) that has materially affected, or is reasonably likely to materially affect, the registrant's internal control over financial reporting; and </P>
<P style="line-height:9.5pt; margin:0px; font-family:Arial; font-size:7.5pt" align=justify>&nbsp;&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:32.667px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>5. The registrant's other certifying officer and I have disclosed, based on our most recent evaluation of internal control over financial reporting, to the registrant's auditors and the audit committee of the registrant's board of directors (or persons performing the equivalent functions): </P>
<P style="line-height:9.5pt; margin:0px; font-family:Arial; font-size:7.5pt" align=justify>&nbsp;&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:32.6px; text-indent:32.667px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>(a) All significant deficiencies and material weaknesses in the design or operation of internal control over financial reporting which are reasonably likely to adversely affect the registrant's ability to record, process, summarize and report financial information; and </P>
<P style="line-height:9.5pt; margin:0px; font-family:Arial; font-size:7.5pt" align=justify>&nbsp;&nbsp;</P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:66px; font-family:Arial">(b) Any fraud, whether or not material, that involves management or other employees who have a significant role in the registrant's internal control over financial reporting.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial">Date: March 17, 2008</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>

<TYPE>EX-31
<SEQUENCE>9
<FILENAME>exh312.htm
<DESCRIPTION>EXHIBIT 31.2
<TEXT>
<!doctype html public "-//IETF//DTD HTML//EN">
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>To Our Shareholders</TITLE>
<META NAME="author" CONTENT="IHC">
<META NAME="date" CONTENT="03/11/2008">
</HEAD>
<BODY style="line-height:12pt; font-family:Times New Roman; font-size:10pt; color:#000000">
<DIV style="width:672px"><P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial" align=right><B>Exhibit 31.2</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=right><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial" align=center><B>CERTIFICATION PURSUANT TO RULE 13A-14(a) OR 15D-14(a) OF THE SECURITIES </B></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial" align=center><B>EXCHANGE ACT OF 1934, AS ADOPTED PURSUANT TO SECTION 302 OF THE </B></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial" align=center><B>SARBANES-OXLEY ACT OF 2002 </B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial">I,&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Teresa A. Herbert, certify that:</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:32.667px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>1. I have reviewed this annual report on Form 10-K of American Independence Corp;</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:32.667px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>2. Based on my knowledge, this report does not contain any untrue statement of a material fact or omit to state a material fact necessary to make the statements made, in light of the circumstances under which such statements were made, not misleading with respect to the period covered by this report;</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:32.667px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>3. Based on my knowledge, the financial statements, and other financial information included in this report, fairly present in all material respects the financial condition, results of operations and cash flows of the registrant as of, and for, the periods presented in this report;</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:32.667px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>4. The registrant's other certifying officer and I are responsible for establishing and maintaining disclosure controls and procedures (as defined in Exchange Act Rules 13a-15(e) and 15d-15(e)) and internal control over financial reporting (as defined in Exchange Act Rules 13a-15(f) and 15d-15(f)) for the registrant and have:</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:32.6px; text-indent:32.667px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>(a) Designed such disclosure controls and procedures, or caused such disclosure controls and procedures to be designed under our supervision, to ensure that material information relating to the registrant, including its consolidated subsidiaries, is made known to us by others within those entities, particularly during the period in which this report is being prepared;</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:32.6px; text-indent:32.667px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>(b) Designed such internal control over financial reporting, or caused such internal control over financial reporting to be designed under our supervision, to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles;</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:32.6px; text-indent:32.667px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>(c) Evaluated the effectiveness of the registrant's disclosure controls and procedures and presented in this report our conclusions about the effectiveness of the disclosure controls and procedures, as of the end of the period covered by this report based on such evaluation; and</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:32.6px; text-indent:32.667px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>(d) Disclosed in this report any change in the registrant's internal control over financial reporting that occurred during the registrant's most recent fiscal quarter (the registrant's fourth fiscal quarter in the case of an annual report) that has materially affected, or is reasonably likely to materially affect, the registrant's internal control over financial reporting; and</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:32.667px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>5. The registrant's other certifying officer and I have disclosed, based on our most recent evaluation of internal control over financial reporting, to the registrant's auditors and the audit committee of the registrant's board of directors (or persons performing the equivalent functions):</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:32.6px; text-indent:32.667px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>(a) All significant deficiencies and material weaknesses in the design or operation of internal control over financial reporting which are reasonably likely to adversely affect the registrant's ability to record, process, summarize and report financial information; and</P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:66px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>(b) Any fraud, whether or not material, that involves management or other employees who have a significant role in the registrant's internal control over financial reporting.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial">Date: March 17, 2008</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<TABLE style="font-size:10pt" cellspacing=0><TR height=0 style="font-size:0; display:none"><TD width=202.4></TD><TD width=1.333></TD><TD width=1.333></TD><TD width=1.333></TD></TR>
<TR><TD valign=top width=202.4><P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial"><U>/s/&nbsp;&nbsp; Teresa A. Herbert</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial">Vice President </P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial">Chief Financial Officer </P>
</TD><TD valign=top width=1.333><P>&nbsp;</P></TD><TD valign=top width=1.333><P>&nbsp;</P></TD><TD valign=top width=1.333><P>&nbsp;</P></TD></TR>
</TABLE>
<P style="margin:6.667px" align=right><BR></P>
<P style="margin:6.667px" align=right><BR>
<BR></P>
</DIV></BODY>

</HTML>

<DESCRIPTION>EXHIBIT 32.1
<TEXT>
<!doctype html public "-//IETF//DTD HTML//EN">
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>To Our Shareholders</TITLE>
<META NAME="author" CONTENT="IHC">
<META NAME="date" CONTENT="03/11/2008">
</HEAD>
<BODY style="line-height:12pt; font-family:Times New Roman; font-size:10pt; color:#000000">
<DIV style="width:672px"><P style="margin-top:5.533px; margin-bottom:5.533px; font-family:Arial" align=right><B>Exhibit 32.1</B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial" align=center><B>CERTIFICATION PURSUANT TO </B></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial" align=center><B>18 U.S.C. SECTION 1350, </B></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial" align=center><B>AS ADOPTED PURSUANT TO </B></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial" align=center><B>SECTION 906 OF THE SARBANES-OXLEY ACT OF 2002 </B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:37.333px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>In connection with the Annual Report of American Independence Corp. (the &quot;Company&quot;) on Form 10-K for the period ending December 31, 2007 as filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission on the date hereof (the &quot;Report&quot;), I, Roy T. K. Thung, Chief Executive Officer of the Company, certify, pursuant to 18 U.S.C. ss. 1350, as adopted pursuant to ss. 906 of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002, that to my knowledge:</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-16px; padding-left:46.667px; text-indent:-9.333px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>(1</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:46.667px; text-indent:49.333px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The Report fully complies with the requirements of section&nbsp;13(a) or 15(d) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934; and </P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=justify><BR></P>
<P style="margin-top:0px; margin-bottom:-16px; padding-left:46.667px; text-indent:-9.333px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>(2)</P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:46.667px; text-indent:49.333px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>The information contained in the Report fairly presents, in all material respects, the financial condition and results of operations of the Company.</P>

<!doctype html public "-//IETF//DTD HTML//EN">
<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>To Our Shareholders</TITLE>
<META NAME="author" CONTENT="IHC">
<META NAME="date" CONTENT="03/11/2008">
</HEAD>
<BODY style="line-height:12pt; font-family:Times New Roman; font-size:10pt; color:#000000">
<DIV style="width:672px"><P style="margin:0px; padding-left:576px; font-family:Arial"><B>Exhibit&nbsp;32.2 </B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=right><BR></P>
<A NAME="a2129092zex_32_2_htm_kw2502_internationa"></A><A NAME="a2129092zex_32_2_htm_toc_kw2502_2"></A><P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial" align=center><B>CERTIFICATION PURSUANT TO </B></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial" align=center><B>18 U.S.C. SECTION 1350, </B></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial" align=center><B>AS ADOPTED PURSUANT TO </B></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial" align=center><B>SECTION 906 OF THE SARBANES-OXLEY ACT OF 2002 </B></P>
<P style="margin:0px" align=center><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; text-indent:37.333px; font-family:Arial" align=justify>In connection with the Annual Report of American Independence Corp. (the &quot;Company&quot;) on Form&nbsp;10-K for the period ending December&nbsp;31, 2007 as filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission on the date hereof (the &quot;Report&quot;), I, Teresa A. Herbert Vice President, Chief Financial Officer of the Company, certify, pursuant to 18&nbsp;U.S.C. ss. 1350, as adopted pursuant to ss. 906 of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002, that to my knowledge:</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:46.667px; text-indent:-9.333px; font-family:Arial">(1) &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Report fully complies with the requirements of section&nbsp;13(a) or 15(d) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934; and </P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; padding-left:46.667px; text-indent:-9.333px; font-family:Arial">(2) &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The information contained in the Report fairly presents, in all material respects, the financial condition and results of operations of the Company.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<TABLE style="font-size:10pt" cellspacing=0><TR height=0 style="font-size:0; display:none"><TD width=404.8></TD><TD width=1.333></TD><TD width=1.333></TD><TD width=1.333></TD></TR>
<TR><TD valign=top width=404.8><P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial"><U>/s/ Teresa A. Herbert</U></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial">Vice President, Chief Financial Officer </P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial">March 17, 2008 </P>
</TD><TD valign=top width=1.333><P>&nbsp;</P></TD><TD valign=top width=1.333><P>&nbsp;</P></TD><TD valign=top width=1.333><P>&nbsp;</P></TD></TR>
</TABLE>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR></P>
<P style="margin:0px; font-family:Arial">A signed original of this written statement required by Section 906 has been provided to the Company and will be retained by the Company and furnished to the Securities and Exchange Commission or its staff upon request.</P>
<P style="margin:0px"><BR>
